I was very happy about this purchase.

This was the moment that this introduced me intro the persona franchise. Remember that the persona series was mostly playstation exclusive so a lot of persona fans who don't own playstations would usually watch youtube gameplays of it. Atlus broke that rule when this released. It was the first persona series that was on steam and OH BOY! WHAT A RELEASE THIS WAS! This sold extremely well and it became the starter entry to the persona series as well as the next standard for all persona games. 

In terms of the game, its Persona 4 Golden! What else do you expect! Its a PC ports with improvements according to sources that I will surely find later :trollface: and a good PC port at that. Plus this games goes really cheap during sales so get it while the sales are happening.

But this is not a review on why the game is good, I want to thank the game for making me love the persona franchise. All the good memories spent on the persona series will not go to waste.

150300405.review: i've read it's a slow burn game, but to me if you can't get my attention at the beginning i just don't have any desire to play more. the farthest i went was beating the first dungeon and it might just be me coming from p5 to p4, but i felt this game was very boring, though i only played a couple hours of p5 before deciding that i should play 4 then 5, i enjoyed what i had played of 5. the procedurally generated dungeons make them very boring. initiating combat is very confusing as if i attack from any angle, but the back i start standard combat, if they attack me from any angle i start at a disadvantage, if i attack them from the back i have a 50/50 chance to start at advantage, i don't know whether or not them being alerted affects this but since there is no sneaking or walking animation when pushing the analog stick slightly i feel like sneaking isn't a thing in this and they always seem to get alerted by the time i attack them anyway, and if they just run into me from the back they starts with advantage, while if we just run into each other it's a 50/50 chance that i starts with disadvantage and if i run into them from the back i start standard combat. I feel like games like earthbound and the mario rpgs make the best ways to initiating combat in a turn based rpg i.e. earthbound with running into their back or them running into yours determined who's at advantage or mario rps where it's who attacks who first on the field, but persona 4 feels like it took from both without properly implementing either. i don't like how the sos just starts and isn't a yes or no prompt as i would accidentally press starts as i'm more used to start being a menu button in other games and while i could get used to it i chose to just change it to a button that isn't used to avoid accidentally pressing it. while i understand that the protagonist is supposed to be the player's character i feel that for a rpg with teams that the team is the player's characters as i will never understand that when the protag dies that's a game over state, i hate this even in games i like such as kingdom hearts, why would the party just lose when the protag dies they just choose to not revive or bring him out? they all just lose instantly without him? it makes no sense, at least 3 had an explanation, but 4 has none. finally i feel like the characters are idiotic as none of them ran to cover a character's mouth to prevent that person from saying the line "you're not me" and thus prevent a boss fight. at least after the second time they should be doing this, no need to fight enemies that could be avoided.

150240324.review:
If you like murder mystery and are fine with turn based rpg, then you will like this game. I came to this series after hearing a lot of fans of Danganronpa like this game, and I was not disappointed. The graphics are a little older, and the gameplay can require a bit of grinding, but rest assured it is worth it. 

The rest of this review is targeted toward people who played Persona 5 and came back to this after.

If you are coming back to this game after playing Persona 5, I would definitely say go for it. I went the opposite direction (so P4G to P5R), but I don't think it's a problem to go backwards. There is a lot of things that haven't aged the best, but if you can look past it this is a very amazing game that has actually queer characters and not just baiting so if that's up your alley definitely check it out. 

There is a lot character development in the skill links, but some can be a bit problematic *cough nurse cough*. Also some good social links are hid behind other links that are less... pleasant. However despite some elements aging poorly, they also were a bit more free to make queer characters outright queer which I appreciate. There are also some implied ones and tbh this is just a good game for if you enjoy shipping. Also fun fact that everyone likes to point out is that Yosuke (the male sidekick character you meet him in the first chapter so not a real spoiler) was originally going to be a romance option before the production cut it. People are still salty to this day. I am one of these people.

I also like the story of this game compared to Persona 5. I would say the twists in Persona 5 were a bit harder to deduce, but I really like the usage of Shadows in persona 4. And even if you are obviously suspicious of certain characters, you still need more information to piece things together. Persona 4 still has incentive to keep playing since you don't have all the cards (pun not intended, but welcome). 

Speaking of cards, I will say that going backwards it would be really odd to change methods of attaining personas and changing dungeon systems. Instead of talking with personas you pick between shuffled cards which sometimes have personas and sometimes do other things. However I will say that this system does make the dungeons have more longevity since you can recover SP with this method. This only works after battle though, and only if certain conditions are met in said battle, so SP is still a careful resource and if you want a specific persona then you gotta skip on it. Also you can misclick on picking the card that you want at the end of a battle. So it's a bit change but has its pros and cons. 

I will also say that all the dungeons in this game are like Mementos in P5, so if that was annoying for you that could be a turn off. Also most floors are randomly generated aside from boss floors. There are none of the cool puzzles like in P5, but I think the story and characters is what makes it worth sticking to it. Also if you are like me and playing with a family member on steam you can just have one person grind for you lol. 

All in all I would say definitely play the game if you played persona 5 first, but I thought I should give some warnings ahead of time. Hope you enjoy the game as much as I have :)

150204664.review:
Si estas pensando en empezar la saga persona por aquí -como muchas reseñas lo sugieren- te diría que no. Persona 4 Golden es buenísimo y definitivamente compite hombro a hombro con Persona 5 por quedarse con el titulo del mejor de la saga PERO no es para nada amigable con el jugador promedio, o que no este plenamente acostumbrado a rpg´s, incluso yendo mas al extremo con la saga Shin megami tensei. Mientras sientes que el Persona 5 (que de hecho por aquí recomiendo empezar) te lleva de la mano por medio de sus mecánicas y te las explica de una forma orgánica. Persona 4 no, aquí tocaras su sistema de combate recién a la hora de juego y posiblemente tengas tu primer game over porque un enemigo te encajara cada debilidad posible, lo que se resume en frustracion y posible abandono del juego, o bien obligarte a pasarlo caminando dado que estarás jugando en fácil. 
 Hablando plenamente del juego, es de lejos una de las mejores cosas que puedes jugar, en términos de historia y desarrollo de personajes se nota la rigurosidad que hubo en el proceso, y la forma en que aplica la teoría psicológica en que esta basado todo lo que tiene que ver con esta especie de mundo cognitivo es asombrosa. Tal como cualquier teoría psicoanalista se repasa un buen rato por la sexualidad de los personajes que protagonizan las mazmorras (bueno, al menos en algunas) por lo que si eres conocedor del asunto disfrutaras entendiendo las analogías y metáforas del entorno y enemigos.

150028884.review:
[h1] Another Excellent Entry in the Persona Series [/h1]
Just like Persona 3 , Persona 4 offers a good story, likable characters, and fun game play.  Persona 3 still has the best story and characters of the modern Persona games, but 4's are solid as well.  Where Persona 4 really shines is how it expands on the social links and the activities around town.  Every social link is well crafted and helps add depth to the supporting characters and the setting.  
The port Atlus developed for Persona 4 is better than the one they created for Persona 3.  The characters and backgrounds look polished and there are no audio issues this time around.  I just wish Persona 3 got this much love for its port.
Overall, Persona 4 is a fantastic game.  The characters are likable and the story is good. Its biggest improvement overall is to the social links.  Any Persona or JRPG fan should definitely give it a try.

149995812.review:
So, I originally bought Persona 4 when it was released on the Vita, years ago. I probably played about 15-20 hours of it and life took over. More than a decade later, I have returned to it on PC after buying the 'Golden' remake. I knew the game was quality but I didn't quite realise what I was in for in terms of its entire experience this time around.

Persona 4 (whether it is the original or Golden) is one of the best games I've every played, and I was born in the 80's. Do not hesitate to buy the game. In terms of the philosophical aspects of the game, as well as the friendship and dating aspects of the game (albeit very casual), these actually taught me a lot in terms of self reflection and self improvement. I truly believe Persona 4 is a game that can make you a better person. I wish that I was exposed to it in my early teens or 20s or even 30s. With a rough childhood, experiences of neglect, self hatred and abuse, I feel that this game really impacted me personally. There is something in here for everyone out there to relate to, and it is both heartwarming as well as healing. 
Persona is a game that is more than what it is, and it encapsulates what is a majestic vision that only the Japanese could possibly envision and implement successfully. By the time you get into it, you will find yourself with an affinity towards the characters that borders on surreal.

Just some important points if you're considering this game:
1) You will have to time sink and grind. That is part of the game. Once you get used to it and have your goal in mind, this won't be too much of a problem.

2) You can't play this game with a mouse. While you can get by with the keyboard, I would recommend a controller for this game.

3) On PC (and perhaps modern consoles?) The 'fishing game' is basically impossible because the fishing cursor moves far too quick. I had to forego fishing as a quest and for that reason, achievement hunters out there may find this part of the game frustrating. Not a big deal as it doesn't affect things all too much.

4) Try to avoid spoilers and guides with the exception of 3 circumstances. Firstly to get yourself off to a good start. Secondly, only in situations where you may be stuck and can't find something. Or thirdly at the late game after the reveal. There are story elements in the form of spoilers that will really ruin the experience if exposed too early. So avoid the mistake of reading ahead or checking videos on YouTube (where I spotted videos with titles that wrecked the story for me).

5) It's worth watching the anime AFTER playing the game.

6) The soundtrack that comes with the Steam version of the game is not the (only) soundtrack you will want. You SHOULD separately purchase the official Persona 4 soundtrack by composer Shoji Meguro, which contains pretty much all the songs you will hear and love by the end of the game.

Do not be fooled by the age of Persona 4. Atlus and Sega have done an absolutely exceptional job and this is a 10 out of 10 effort. Don't hesitate to buy it. It's a timeless experience you will want to dedicate some 80-100 hours into.

149969843.review: P4G was my first foray into JRPGs on the Vita, and it did not disappoint. If you haven't played this game yet, you're doing a disservice to yourself. This game shouldn't be "overwhelming positive" on Steam, it should be universally positive. It's that good of a game, and beloved by almost everyone who's played it. Some of the themes can be a bit uncomfortable (those who have played know the ones), but as a queer person myself, I think the game handles them pretty well. Especially given that the original story itself was from 2008. At first glance, the themes can come off a little offensive. But when you sit and think about the character, how they've interacted with the world around them, how the world has interacted back, their personality, etc, it begins to make a lot more sense, and comes together very cohesively. The game and characters are very well written, even the ones that deal with queerness. All games have their flaws, including this one, but the things it does right, it does *right.* And most of the things it does, are done right, if that makes sense. I don't know what else to say other than this is a game you have to experience for yourself, even if you come away disliking some or all of it (you probably won't, but you might). This game is truly one of the best in the genre. So if you like JRPGs, give this a shot.

149779247.review:
Every bit as good as its successor, centred around a more intimate, personal theme of accepting yourself and striving for the truth. This theme is most present in the social link aspect of the game, which is done excellently, deepening your investment in these characters, specifically your fellow party members, by telling these very emphatic human stories. Additionally, this also furthers your immersion, making the setting of Inaba feel less like just a game world and more like a real place with real people, which is funny when the map of Inaba is so limited. 

While I certainly missed the intricate palaces from Persona 5, Persona 4 by no means has weak dungeon crawling, as each dungeon still oozes personality, and I generally found the battles on Hard difficulty more consistently engaging than Persona 5 Royal even though it has more complex combat due to Baton Pass and Technical. This is because in Persona 5 Royal it is much easier to start battles with player advantage and battles are frequently over before the enemies’ turn whilst this is less the case in Persona 4 forcing you to consider your moves better and play more strategically. However, I do think Persona 5 still has Persona 4 beat on boss battles both visually and mechanically. The visual design of Persona 4’s bosses are still strong though, reaching the end of each dungeon was always a highlight, as I loved seeing how the twisted shadow of each victim would manifest. As in any Persona game the music is fantastic and does an excellent job of capturing the essence of the game. 

Additionally, the scenes of the investigation team hanging out do a great job in convincing you that the group are genuine friends, and it was always a joy watching the characters interact with each other and seeing their relationships develop during these. Persona 4 is downright hilarious at times too which I can’t say about many other games. 

In conclusion I think the best word that describes Persona 4 is ‘genuine’, and I think that is an amazing achievement.

149641346.review:
As is expected out of a Persona game, there's a lot to enjoy about P4G, and I do definitely recommend it for its core gameplay mechanics. 

However:

As someone whose first introduction to the Persona series was Persona 5 Royal, you will very likely be disappointed if you go in expecting the same tier of game.

My main issues are these:

P4G has procedural dungeons with multiple floors vs P5R's handcrafted palaces. This is a huge aspect of the fun I had with P5R, so the procedural generation was very boring and tedious and eventually I lowered difficulty just so I could skip around shadows and not be screwed for the boss fights.

P5R does a fantastic job of giving most of the main cast a good amount of screen time without ever feeling like character involvement is being shoehorned in. Group scenes are done in such a way that there are clearly characters with the main focus from scene to scene. P4G on the other hand, does its utmost to make sure every character always gets a word in, but it's usually redundant and again just becomes boring and tedious. I generally think the writing quality of P5R is just so exceptional that clearly any other game will have a hard time being compared to it, but even so I found this aspect lackluster.

Finally, and this is a problem I had with some parts of P5R as well, but to a lesser extent, the music cues are all over the place, and make empathizing with the cast more difficult. A few of the tracks, especially the ones meant to be somber, are played far too frequently for the emotional beats to hit properly. A more understated use of the background tracks within scenes would have helped immensely.

As a little aside, if you're ever stuck on what to do in a dungeon, be very careful of where you go to find playthrough help. Some of what I found as well as some reviews here spoiled the culprit which completely sullied half the game for me. I understand it's an older game, but that was an incredibly annoying thing to have to deal with.

149266612.review:
I had known about the Persona franchise for some time when I purchased this. A former friend had told me countless times about it in high school, and how much he admired it. I desired greatly to play it, but never had the money to get a Vita in order to play. 

When this came out on Steam, I had really no choice except to buy it. What followed was a great experience. I played it through a sort of midpoint in my life between a chaotic era and new beginnings. It really helped me through the process of change.

I fell in love with the everything. The characters, the setting, the music. The combat, the enemies, the Personas. All of it was so fresh for me. I played it pretty much every day, enjoying every moment of the story and anticipating the end.

When I did finish the game, I was left with a profound sense of accomplishment. This is a long fucking game with a lot of moments dedicated to dialogue and plenty of time spent grinding, plenty of deaths I would have to go back to checkpoints because of, and honestly instances where I simply enjoyed the soundtrack as I switched focus to talk to a friend while playing. My save sat somewhere in the ballpark of 65 to 70 hours and I was proud of it. I had that sense of loss every gamer knows when they finish a good fucking game, but it was bittersweet. I still was left with a net good, I'd say.

Definitely play this game. It is a classic, with a wonderful story and great mechanics, in terms of combat and plenty else. I can't speak from the position of someone with hundreds of hours and who knows every in and out of this game, but I can speak as someone who loved the hell out of this game.

149177004.review:
While the SMT series has no shortage of classics, this one certainly belongs up there. 
Persona 4 Golden does suffer from issues such as a very mind numbing mid game, however the later half of the game completely saves it in my eyes, giving us some of the greatest story telling not just in gaming but in media as a whole.  With a fantastic cast of characters to love and explore, it surely is a fantastic experience to create bonds with characters who feel like complex people with goals, aspirations, insecurities, etc etc. The fantastic soundtrack from the epic to the somber that almost never feels out of place. 
While I do think the original Persona 4 is the superior game, do not make the mistake of skipping this one, while not a master piece, it is certainly close to one in regards to story.
In regards to gameplay, it takes after other SMT games, especially Persona 3 with some changes added in, that can help the experience some what, it does however suffer from the sometimes mind numbing stuff that can plague jrpgs such as grinding. Unlike most others though tough fights require insane strategy even on easier difficulties that can make game play engaging and fulfilling to beat a boss. 
Overall: 8.5/10 play it, it is truly an experience worth having.

I appreciated the writing for the most part, and the characters were believable with an immersive environment. The fantasy aspects didn't feel forced. However, I guess it wasn't a great fit for me due to the lack of good-looking characters and the absence of a happy ending. I dislike the notion of having to replay a game multiple times to get the "proper" ending or to be allowed to finish achievements. I also noticed a disproportionate amount of humor at the expense of boys compared to girls. If they make fun of girls, then shortly after, boys get it much worse.

Mechanically, the combat was pretty good, and the persona unlocks were interesting. However, I really disliked the constant time limit, which relates to the, in my opinion, bad "must replay" to get/complete all content/stats/relationships/quests.

I realize I may not be in the majority, looking at the high Steam score. But for me, it is slightly above average. I enjoyed Tales Of Arise much more, and probably even FFXV, despite it being quite dark for me too.

After swearing off of JRPGs after a bad experience with Dragon Quest, Persona 4 showed me that the genre CAN be fun. It's so stylish and fun in its art design, music, and characters. I turned up the XP gain from one of its many difficulty options and I never had an issue with having to grind. The Social Link aspect was my favorite part of the game. I loved to learn more about the characters through these interactions.

My only complaint with Persona 4 is how obtuse it can be at times, especially for the end of the game and its "Golden" content. Thankfully I made multiple saves because the game ended much earlier than it should have(on multiple occasions). Even with whatever negative feelings I have, this is one of the most unique games I've experienced in a long time. I'm looking forward to playing it again later down the time(and hopefully not taking 2 years to finish).

To be honest, I never anticipated enjoying this game as much as I did with Persona 5. After completing Persona 5 Royal, my expectations were modest, given how much fun I had previously. However, this game exceeded my expectations.

At first, you will feel a bit like running errands, doing quests before deadlines and such. But as the story progresses, that's when you can really feel how well the story was written. Every one of your friends within the game feels so real, as if you are truly there with them, enjoying the student life in the small country town of Inaba. Though I have to agree that some of the jokes in the game are really outdated and feel a bit cringey (actually, it's bear-able,iykwim), the overall experience is irreplaceable.

After all, this is such a great game with great soundtracks. If you don't mind old graphics and jokes, this game will treat you well with its ingenious plot writing and an unforgettable experience!

P.S: Chie's the best girl, by the way.

148378643.review:
This game is not to be missed, I purchased it based on the reviews on here and to sum it up they simply do not do the game justice.

To sum the game up, it is like a successful cross between Final Fantasy and Jade Cocoon (one for the older RPG fans).  

Every character has been extremely well thought out and it is definitely catered for the more adult crowd as the language used at times contains swearing however this does nothing but give more believably to some of the main protagonists.

The story without giving away any spoilers is gripping and extremely well told and thought out and at times it is extremely dark and deep, 

The only downside, dungeons are repetitive and there seems to be no real thought put in with that side of the game play but for anyone who likes turn based combat games this should not be a put off as the story telling way outweighs this oversight.

Never has a game made me go through a whirlwind of emotions between laughing through the extremely witty humour and crying out of sadness.

Highly recommended.

P4G has subpar pacing, terrible 3d character models, lacks QoL features, pretty meh dungeons, audio that did not receive a proper high-frequency sibilant filtering, and a fake widescreen that is just the OG 4:3 screen zoomed in...

THAT BEING SAID...

I love the TV trope, and although I do love and prefer the heavily embedded themes that P5 has, where most animations and locations have dark Red-n-black starred themes, there is no doubt I oddly also enjoy P4Gs simplicity in remaining free from that. A must play for Persona fans and a great choice for those willing to get through a slow start and some grinding to experience a well fleshed out anime story, essentially.

148057807.review:
Persona 4 Golden is a shining gem in the world of video games, a timeless classic that continues to captivate players with its brilliant storytelling, meticulously crafted characters, and the exceptional ability to evoke real and hard-hitting emotions. Originally released on the PlayStation 2 and later enhanced for the PlayStation Vita, then released to Steam and other platforms, this game remains a testament to the power of storytelling in the medium of video games.

Storytelling: 10/10
The narrative of Persona 4 Golden is a work of art. It begins with your character, the silent protagonist, moving to the rural town of Inaba and quickly immerses you in a suspenseful murder mystery. This story is meticulously crafted, masterfully weaving elements of mystery, suspense, and supernatural intrigue. The pacing is impeccable, with each in-game day offering a new layer of the story, allowing players to slowly unravel the mystery behind the Midnight Channel and the strange occurrences in Inaba. The twists and turns keep you engaged, and the revelations are both surprising and thought-provoking.

One of the game's strengths is its exploration of the human psyche and the inner struggles of its characters. As you forge bonds with your friends and delve into the dungeons of their inner selves, you witness their deepest fears and insecurities. The way the game addresses these issues with empathy and depth is a testament to the craftsmanship behind the storytelling. By the time you reach the climax, you're deeply invested in the lives and fates of the characters, making each emotional beat all the more impactful.

Character Development: 10/10
The characters of Persona 4 Golden are a testament to how well-written and fleshed out video game characters can be. Each character has their own distinct personality, struggles, and growth arcs, making them feel like real people you genuinely care about. As you spend time with them, you get to know their quirks, vulnerabilities, and strengths. The "Social Link" system allows you to deepen your relationships, offering insight into their backgrounds and helping them overcome their personal issues. This not only enhances the game-play but also creates a profound emotional connection with the characters.

The central cast, including Yosuke, Chie, Yukiko, Kanji, Rise, Naoto, and Teddie, are multifaceted and undergo significant development throughout the story. Their personal stories are both heartwarming and heart-wrenching, and you can't help but root for them. The antagonist, too, is brilliantly crafted, adding a layer of complexity to the narrative that's rarely seen in video games.

Emotional Impact: 10/10
The emotional impact of Persona 4 Golden is where it truly shines. This game masterfully tugs at your heartstrings. It's impossible not to feel a strong connection to the characters as you watch them grapple with their inner demons and grow through adversity. The game doesn't shy away from addressing sensitive themes like identity, sexuality, acceptance, and the masks people wear to hide their true selves.

The final act of Persona 4 Golden is a roller-coaster of emotions, as you confront the true nature of the villain and help your friends confront their innermost fears. The climax is gut-wrenching and awe-inspiring in equal measure, and it leaves a lasting impact on players.

In conclusion, Persona 4 Golden is a game that excels in storytelling, character development, and evoking genuine, hard-hitting emotions. Its unforgettable cast, thought-provoking narrative, and profound exploration of human psychology make it a timeless classic in the world of video games. If you haven't experienced this emotional roller-coaster, you're missing out on one of the greatest storytelling achievements in gaming history.

148056309.review:
Persona 4 Golden is quite possibly the most perfectly crafted high school slice-of-life JRPG video game ever made currently.

*** NPC Design ***

The characters all have personalities and developments that'll make you cross your fingers that none of them, and i mean literally NONE of the characters die or even get hurt because how beautifully complimentary their designs are.

*** Combat System ***

The combat system has a decent growth curve as you will start out weak due to the impact having multiple personas has on the games flow, this combat system is the only system i've seen that actually makes the concept of switching out personas for specific useful spells constantly, makes usage of even the worst personas, ergo no persona is left behind.

*** The Music ***

The sound tracks of this game is the best i've ever heard in any Persona (TM) video game so far. It fits the student life aesthetic of the protagonist and gives the environments more character, anyone who hasn't started the game yet, enjoy the eargasms, you'll wish you could listen to the music for the first time again, i know i have, hah!

/////  THE CONCLUSION BOIS //////

This game is absolutely worth getting, as a matter of fact i think every steam account should own it, it's an amazing experience to not miss out on, better to get this video game when it goes on sale since it is a Playstation 2 game and from the 2000's era, the price is kinda high right now for such a beautiful relic. But you can even purchase it RIGHT NOW if you're inpatient. No regrets, it's well-worth the price if you can afford to do so.

147862370.review: I'm a fan of the Persona series of games (and a lesser fan of the Shin Megami Tensei series) and I think the most intriguing thing about these games is the way they combine multiple genres.  You have an overall RPG storyline, wherein you have to master a time management game in order to boost your levels in a relationship simulator in order to obtain bonuses for your characters in a dungeon crawler - four games for the price of one, really.  Plus the storylines and characters are interesting.  The main thing I'd caution new players to the series about is making assumptions about where the storyline and the character journeys are going based on Western cultural tropes and narratives - always remember this isn't a Western narrative, and as a result, the underlying assumptions are very different around questions of individuality and group responsibility.

147265008.review:
Unraveling Mysteries - Persona 4 Golden Review

After investing a solid 97 hours and kicking off a New Game+ session, Persona 4 Golden has left an indelible mark on my gaming experience. Having initially explored the Persona universe through Persona 5 Royal, Persona 4 Golden brings a distinctive flavor to the table.

One of the standout features is undoubtedly the enigmatic storyline. Persona 4 excels in building suspense and curiosity, keeping me hooked on the mysteries unfolding in the game. The "Shuffle Time" mechanic adds a layer of unpredictability that I found quite enjoyable, providing a different dynamic compared to Persona 5.

Persona 4's strengths lie in its engaging characters and a plot that keeps you guessing. While the endgame lacks the tough decision-making element (there really only is 1 Choice that makes sense), it doesn't take away from the overall experience. The narrative unfolds seamlessly, and the characters' development is both heartwarming and impactful.

On the musical front, the soundtrack is undeniably impressive, creating a fitting atmosphere for the game. However, it's worth noting that, in my opinion, it doesn't quite reach the heights of the Persona 5 soundtrack. Persona 5 set a high bar with its unforgettable tunes, and while Persona 4's soundtrack is excellent, it doesn't quite match the same level of brilliance.

In conclusion, Persona 4 Golden is a remarkable addition to the Persona series, offering a captivating journey filled with mysteries and memorable moments. If you're a fan of deep narratives, well-crafted characters, and a touch of suspense, Persona 4 Golden is a must-play.

147005322.review:
I could experience what being likable was like. 10 out of 10. 



But jokes aside, it's the best game i've played so far. At first, the whole JRPG fighting and the graphics weren't that appealing for me. However, as i got used to the game, i was fully amazed how well the game was planned out.

First of all, the whole background and stage really gives the early 2010s vibe which gives a big nostalgic feels. The fashion and the art style, somehow even the BGM makes me feel like i'm a highschool student in 2010. 

The main story is full of surprises, it's really well-written and witty. And the anime cut scenes that appear time to time are always on point. 

What REALLY lured me in was the side stories. And i'm not just talking about the side characters. Every NPC in this game has their backstory. The dialogues of all mob characters vary every time you talk to them. Personally, the dialogues are the most important part of this game. It gives replay values as the characters all show different reactions to the player's choice. 

The fact you can fully bond with all the side characters also made this game more likable than other games. Some games make perfectly well structured into a blunt talking doll. Persona, however, never waste their characters. They show the whole iceberg and the player does a big part revealing the iceberg.  

Also, there are tons of collectible stuff you can gather throughout the game. So, if you're a collector, you'll have to put a reasonable amount of time in this game. But, i can assure you, it ain't boring. 

 In the end, if you are not sure of buying this game, i highly suggest playing it.

So. I was never a big fan of these type of games. 

Quite a few friends kept telling me to try Persona/Shin Megami Tensei.
One friend pushed me to try it.

I hate him.
I finished my first playthrough and got what i feel is the best ending. This game has heart, has soul and music that pulls your heartstrings.

For people that never played JRPG's this is a fantastic introduction to the concept, whether youre in there for the story, for collecting or for the RPsocial mechanical aspects of the game. Persona 4 Golden has a wonderful story where your actions and choices affect how youre going through the game and whether you want to cry tears of joy or tears of sorrow.
Yep. Cry. Prepare for it.

Wether its the beautiful soundtrack, the intense moments, the hilarious back and forths or the staggering amount of playstyles through the creation and fusion of your persona.

If you're not sure whether to try it, from one doubter to another. GIVE IT A SHOT.  The intro might be fairly long and slow but eventually you wish you had more time to play this game as every day spend in game is another step closer to the end.

146733000.review:
I can see why this game is so beloved, if I played it on the PS2 when it was released I think it would be a 5/5 game for me. The vibes are impeccable hanging out in a small town in the countryside of Japan. Trying to solve a murder mystery with your friends is a blast and all of the characters are really great. The game tries to tackle deep subjects like depression, loneliness, finding yourself, and not being embarrassed for who you are. It succeeds in saying something about these topics MOST of the time but does falter in certain places.

The soundtrack is wall to wall bangers and I cannot wait for the vinyl of the soundtrack I ordered as I will be listening to this music for years to come.

For me the major drawback of the game is the dungeon portion. It truly feels like a game from the early 2000's. The randomly generated generic floors did not do enough to break up the more simplistic turn based fights. It got to the point where I dreaded that part of the game so I just turned the difficulty all the way down and blasted through any combat areas. I also think the game would have hit a little harder if I did not get the killer spoiled for me on the internet during my on and off playthrough that went on over the course of 3 years.

146705150.review:
Definitely one of the best games i've ever played. Had a total of 4 playthroughs where i was able to experience many different interactions, the endings and eventually finding a more optimal route to complete the game.

It's the first of the Persona games i play. At first, i was trying to speed through it but that turned out to be a gigantic mistake. It is by taking your time during dialogue, during cutscenes and having a bit of patience with the dungeons that you truly come to bond with the game and its characters. This is one of those games that make you WISH you could play it for the first time again the most. The first time you play through this game is an absolutely amazing experiences with engaging story elements carefully put together and neat details.

There are MANY, MANY things you can do to progress through the story which enables the player great flexibility when it comes to creating your route. Most of the time, you'll spend time with other people, but you must not forget yourself and your own stats.

10/10  [spoiler]Naoto best girl. [/spoiler]

146373339.review:
From the perspective of someone who played Persona 5 first (as I imagine most people buying this will have done), Persona 4 is a fantastic game of it's time period. However it certainly has aged. The dungeons are procedural generated which makes them rather bland and the combat is quite a bit more frustrating. Also, no save points throughout the dungeon, so if you need to go back, if you don't go right back to the same floor you left previously, you get to start all over, making grinding out levels a total pain in the ass.

That all said, the story is interesting, the relationships with the characters make you feel like they're family, and resolving the overall mystery is satisfying. Music is great and the seeds of the stylish UI seen in P5 are present.

I hope one day it gets the Persona 3 Reload treatment, maybe the pain points that came with age can be smoothed out + updated visuals.

146339039.review:
Tras conocer la maravilla que fue Persona 5 Royal estaba más que emocionado de conocer más de esta saga y de todo Megaten, así que he decidido ir de más reciente a más antiguo. Mi siguiente parada entonces era este Persona 4 Golden. Más aún tras saber que se TRADUJO AL ESPAÑOL OFICIALMENTE.

Jugablemente es lo que se puede esperar de un juego de esta saga tras Persona 3, mezcla de simulador social con JRPG por turnos.
Tenemos dos planos, el humano y el mundo de dentro de la televisión.
En el humano se nos presenta un estilo de juego en plan Visual Novel donde podremos explorar el pueblo en el que transcurre la historia y decidir como vamos a pasar el tiempo. De primeras habrá que ir a clase pero tras que se acaben seremos libres de hacer lo que queramos como pasar tiempo con nuestros conocidos, buscar un curro con el que ganaremos dinero, comprar armas, armaduras y objetos necesarios para luchar en el mundo de la televisión, estudiar o realizar otras actividades.
Todo esto es necesario para:
-Aumentar el nivel de nuestros Social Link, lo que nos ayudará a la hora de crear nuevas Personas (en el caso de tus compañeros de grupo recibirán nuevas habilidades como resistir un ataque normal, curar estados alterados, derribar o tirar fuera del combate a los enemigos)
-Aumentar las características sociales del protagonista como el carisma, el valor o la inteligencia. Lo que nos ayuda a conseguir nuevos trabajos, nuevos Social Link y nuevas opciones de diálogo.
-Profundizar más en las historias y conflictos personales de cada personaje del juego.

En el mundo de la televisión tendremos la parte de JRPG convencional, nos metemos en dungeon donde luchamos contra enemigos en combates por turnos, la clave que diferencia esta saga de las otras es su forma de luchar. Hay que aprovechar las debilidades de nuestros enemigos para ganar turnos extra, derribarlos a todos y evitar que ellos hagan lo propio con nosotros.
Aquí el "darle a atacar todo el rato" no funciona, la estrategia y conocer bien las habilidades de todo tu grupo es la clave para salir victorioso de los combates.
La lucha y la subida de nivel es importante puesto que te ayudará a crear y conseguir nuevas "Personas" más poderosas y con mejores habilidades que ya tienes, algo así como en Pokémon pero en lugar de capturar bichos los consigues mediante un juego de cartas o fusionándolos.

Esto es algo que todos los juegos de Persona tienen ¿Qué tiene Persona 4 para destacar frente al resto?
La historia.

En esta ocasión estamos ante una trama de misterio e investigación donde en el pueblo de Inaba se están sucediendo una serie de asesinatos para los que la policía, sorpresa, no sabe cómo resolver. Todo esto está relacionado con un canal de televisión que aparece de noche los días de lluvia y con un mundo alterno dentro de dicho canal al que solo nuestros protas tienen acceso. De este modo, los protas forman un equipo de investigación hecho para descubrir quién es el asesino de Inaba.

No solo es una gran historia de investigación y misterio, sino que además es una historia introspectiva donde conoceremos a profundidad los miedos, paranoias y dudas de todos los integrantes de nuestro grupo, a la par que intentamos que estos se vayan aceptando a si mismos. Poco a poco se verá que esto de no aceptarse a uno mismo es un mal que atañe a toda la sociedad del pueblo y está relacionado con la extraña niebla que aparece tras varios días de lluvia.

Mi conclusión es que este es uno de los mejores juegos de la saga Persona y uno de mis JRPG preferidos de toda la vida.
MUY RECOMENDABLE TANTO SI HAS JUGADO PREVIAMENTE PERSONA 5 COMO NO.

PD: Si quieres acceder al contenido extra de la versión Golden, sube el Social Link de Marie al Nivel 10 tan rápido como puedas.

146301171.review:
Every time I replay this game, every time I return to Inaba, it feels a little like returning home. Every time I finish it, every time I say goodbye to the cast, a little part of me stays behind.

That sounds dramatic, I know, trust me I know, but it's true. I've never played a game that has a cast quite like P4. The bonds between the members of the Investigation Team feel like genuine friendships. The beauty of P4 is that it makes you feel like they're your friends too. You grow to genuinely care for these characters, and want to spend as much time as you can with them before your time with them runs out.

The gameplay is your usual JRPG fare, the writing is sometimes questionable, but none of that matters. The reason you play this game is for the story and the cast (and the incredible soundtrack). 

If you have any qualms at all, cast them aside. Buy this game and experience for yourself just how a sense of community and friendship can be conveyed in a piece of media.

Also, Rise best girl

I know my icon gives me away as a 5head but like. I just do not like this game. Its got all the persona tropes and trappings and that clearly gives it enough for most to like it but the gameplay its wrapped in just feels so flat and slow to me. The dungeons bored me, the side quests did not interest me (the confidants did for the record), and the party is a mixed bag. I like most of them well enough they all have good moments but they have just too many scenes that come off as abrasive rather than charming.

Also a lot of their arcs just don't work for me? Kanji and Naoto have been the center of debate for 15 years now for good reason. Honestly I find their arcs fine if a little boring? Like yeah it is totally fine for Kanji to be a straight guy and be into feminine things but like. I don't find much value in that? I don't find it homophobic that he isn't gay but it just isn't saying much interesting to me. It probably resonated more in 2008 but it just feels like a big deal about nothing now. Especially combined with Yosuke just being a total dick to him for the rest of the game for being gay it just feels off. 

Honestly though the arc that really pissed me off was Yukiko's. She was my favorite character and I loved how her dungeon encapsulated and visualized her struggles in relation to her family business. Then when you do her social link she decides... to take over the family business. Which yeah they gave reasons for it but doesn't mean I liked the reasons. It just makes the game feel like the things you do often don't end up mattering long term story wise.

I think I could still "recommend" this game I know there is a lot to like in it and clearly most who play do end up enjoying it. But personally I just gotta give it the thumbs down.

Also why do the colors in golden look so much worse than the PS2 game? The mood is really tuned down its a shame.

145507994.review:
If I had a proper rating scale to give this game, it'd get a 6.5/10. But I can't do that, so, yes I do recommend people IF THEY HAVE A LARGE INTEREST.

I am not overly offended by P4's gameplay loop, but the game gets incredibly stale by the latter part of the game, the first optional final dungeon is probably the worst section gameplay-wise in the entire game, and the effort of doing everything to even get to the final boss, only for one of the least memorable boss fights possible... leaves a sour taste in my mouth.

Everything else? Good enough. Main cast varies from excellent (Naoto, Teddie, Kanji) to what did they do to you in Golden cutscenes (Youske), and the side characters vary from the best in the world (Kou) to certainly existing (Nurse.) Combat made sense for a while, although the reuse of enemies absolutely wore its novelty quickly after the fifth Basalt enemy encountered with unique weaknesses. Once you get Megido and any level of Invigorate, encounters become trivialized, and the Chakra ring or Spell Master proceed to truly invalidate everything else remaining. If nothing else, it speeds the game up drastically when you no longer need to worry about the omnidrain enemies late-game.

Shuffle time truly ruined everything, though - I'm a grinder who will abuse every tool, even if I know it actively ruins an experience, and shuffle time just makes the player significantly more powerful than they have any right being. My favorite design-wise is Ippon-Datara, and I wound up by the endgame having a 99 in all stats, Megidolaon-Mind Charge + 2 AOEs my team couldn't cover, Invigorate 3 and Spell Master copy of him. The game became click Mind Charge->Heat Riser Naoto->Masukunda Kanji->delete button.

I'm sure people who aren't me will find more enjoyment out of P4G, especially if they aren't a farmer. For me, the game turned into a slog by the end, but I still have good memories of working through the early game and barely getting everything prepped for the True Ending.

I have never posted a review on this sight before but I just spent 75 hours getting the true ending in this and it might have been one of the greatest gaming experiences of my life. The eclectic residents of Inaba are, in my opinion, the best group of characters I have ever experienced in any form of media, only one of them feels like a character that has been written every other character feels deeply complex and human and this reflects in some of the strongest writting in my opinion that video games have to offer. To me this game more than any other persona game shines more in the social interactions between Yu and the cast compared to the rather lackluster dungeon crawling and decent, but not as incredible as persona 5, combat.

I do however have a few rather small negatives, the main one being that the dungeons can get rather boring especially if like me you have been spoiled by the rich, beautifully crafted dungeons of persona 5, not to say that they are terrible just that they can often become boring esspecially if you have to grind for hours in them (my biggest tip is to set the XP yeild to high in the settings in order to counteract this).

The best of the Persona games (an opinion). The characters and the story is fun and engaging from beginning until the end. 

I used this game to study Japanese. There's quite a bit of audio to listen to that you can listen on repeat if needed. You can change the language of the interface to Japanese (or some other languages), which together with the audio recordings, make this an ideal game for Japanese language practice.

There are better language learning tools out there of course, but as a game, this game serves its purpose rather well.

As for game play itself, it really isn't anything too impressive or difficult. You can become utterly overpowered and destroy everything quite easily. That's a good thing. I'd say most will play this game for the characters and the story rather than the game play. That being said, it is enjoyable enough to not entirely burn you out.

... But you will need to use a guide if you don't want to waste your time and end up missing important story moments.

144850729.review:
It's a solid game and I felt that it was a good introduction to the Persona series for me. It did take me a while to get into it, especially as I took a while to grasp the mechanics and find the motivation to play it more (thank you, Steam Deck!) Once I started getting used to it and had a full party setup, I didn't struggle much once to get through the story with the exception of a few bosses. There is one major gripe I have with the Steam version that I can't ignore. Why does a single player game, let alone a PS2 one have DRM that forces you to go online before you play it?

Moving past that, I enjoyed the story and the setting of Inaba, and I liked the little twists and turns along the way as I progressed further through the story, but some of the dialogue is so cringe and made me feel like I'm way past the game's target demographic, it's a bit of an unfortunate side effect of the game showing its age.

As these dialogue issues are brought up by most people, I'll skip over them but I'll make a point that Rise's obsession with Narukami got me feeling that If I were him, I'd keep a spray bottle filled with holy water on me with my finger always on the trigger, ready to pull it at any given second if she got within 3 feet of me.

Despite my gripes, I really enjoyed the game and I'm glad I started playing it around the time I did as while I was mid-playthrough, an update dropped which added a quick save feature, which tremendously improved my experience as someone that played in short bursts during my work breaks. I'm really glad that there's finally a handheld system out there to facilitate my playthrough of P4G, I say, as I give my PS Vita the nastiest stare.

Took over 82 hours to get the true ending, probably the most hours I've played in a game to just reach the credits. It can feel a bit repetitive especially around halfway through, but the player-made pace of the game makes it incredibly addictive and I constantly found myself saying "just one more day". The story is pretty engaging and each character has their own distinct personality, though occasionally they act more like caricatures than people. I wish there were a few more story events scattered throughout the game, but that's because they're so much fun to watch and goes to show how good the writing can be. The JRPG gameplay was hit-or-miss for me, as sometimes it can be extremely repetitive and you can feel the grind, but it really shines when you can chain critical hits and weaknesses together and seeing your high ranking social links dramatically affect combat (tip I wish I knew earlier -> [spoiler] Maxing out Rise's sl is super powerful[/spoiler]). 
Overall a really well made game and absolutely worth the price if you think it's up your alley. The problems I have are pretty minor considering the scale of the game.

144377925.review: Persona 4 is a game that hasn't aged practically well. It is a fantastic RPG with great characters and an overarching narrative that keeps you invested throughout. The idea of "shadows" and facing one's true self is a great way to showcase our main party's struggles and issues that they have to deal with and flesh them out as characters. The only problem with this is the execution. Both Kanji's and Naoto's shadows and issues often misrepresent their true issues are pretty representative that this game was made in 2008 Japan. Like if the general themes of the dungeons completely got rid of the awful misrepresentation of gay and trans issues, then this game would be so much better. Kanji and Naoto's character don't even go in that direction, instead using those LGBT as an unfortunate mask for their real issues. Maybe some future persona games can better represent these issues but for what we have here, it is not well-aged at all. The dungeon system in this game is pretty uninteresting, all floors feel the same and can get pretty mind-numbing after awhile. But if you can get past these issues, there is a fantastic game underneath that makes you feel like you're apart of this group of friends that transcend the digital space.

144376292.review: Persona 4 is without a doubt one of my favorite games I've played in recent memory, with phenomenal storytelling and an equally incredible soundtrack. The juxtaposition between a high school life-sim and a classic JRPG blends well and creates an experience greater than the sum of its parts. The characters are, for the most part, extremely well written which makes you genuinely care for them, and the game's mystery elements which require you to pick up on subtle cues throughout the story to determine what is happening behind the scenes creates a story that is more gripping than most games I have played. While the true ending can be brute-forced, having a reward for paying attention to these clues can be very gratifying for players who are genuinely invested in the story. The game is decently sized too, taking me about 63.5 hours to beat, not counting deaths and idling. Technically speaking, this is a very stable release in which I only noticed one frame dip in my entire playthrough. While this isn't that impressive considering this is a PlayStation 2 game, it is nice to see the developers took care in making sure this was a quality PC port. My only real gripes with the game lie due to the cultural gap that comes from playing a game intended for Japanese audiences with Western eyes, with more than one occasion in the game leaving me genuinely uncomfortable in regards to how the game treats certain characters. All things considered, I'd say this game is a 9.5/10 which I recommend for most people to at least try, given how little it costs.

144239112.review:
I was in a bad place when I was first introduced to Persona 4 Golden. I would have never touched the game if it weren't for someone making it try it. I'm thankful to myself that I tried it despite my initial thoughts. If I didn't, I wouldn't be able to share that P4G is one of the best single-player game experience I've ever had.

P4G is addicting in many aspects. The way combat is crafted is nothing short of genius. Every fight, even ones where you're grinding for experience points, always require thinking because of the way P4G refines difficulty and resource management. There are always consequences to what you do. Difficult battles push your strategical capabilities. Every challenge overcome makes you feel amazing.

Its story will push you to play even more as each character you're introduced to have their own arc. Depending on how you wish to spend your time, you may choose who and how much your character interacts with others. Relationships that you strengthen feel legitimate. These characters are expertly written, all having clear reasons for their personality, motives, and feelings. Slowing building relationships in P4G makes you feel invested in them like if they were real. Solving the mysteries of Inaba is just as compelling as you work together with the characters you grow so fond of to solve injustices and protect others. There is never a dull moment when playing this game.

If you enjoy any kind of turn-based combat, visual novel, or even just a story to follow, playing this game is a requirement to experience what makes those aspects of a video game fun at its absolute best. P4G goes to show that some games will never age. It is a must-try classic.

144069961.review:
Will update this review after completing my second playthrough. But just from my first experience, it's without a doubt a great, great game that have you truly attached.

Music: 10/10. The music is SO GOOD. It really is. Every track just fits perfectly with what's happening and gets your emotions rolling through uncontrollably. 

Combat: 7/10. In my opinion the weakest part of the game. The system is easy to understand but it's quite clunky and slow at times with too much repetitive corridor maze running grind. It does the job however, and in major, epic fights that are important, the atmosphere truly pulls through. The flaws however are mostly due to this game being quite old for some time now so it's understandable. 

Characters: 10/10. The best description for the cast is that, they work together in this story and game PERFECTLY. Besides each one of them being so so deep and beautiful in their lives at Inaba. Everyone just fits their role and some characters truly elevate your experience in the story.

Graphics/Art: 8/10. Very well designed characters and the scenes around Inaba and surrounding regions. There are a few moments where the character art or graphics show their old, outdated age but it does the job well. 

Story: 100/10. Please just experience P4G story with 0 spoilers from start to finish. You won't regret it. Incredibly emotional story from start to finish and many plot twists with PEAK ARCS that throw you off your chair. I went in with expectations that were COMPLETELY SHATTERED by how the story developed.

Exploration/Content: 9/10. Many many things to do and great events that add to the story development. The town of Inaba itself is small so not much daily exploration but other than that there are tons of content to be explored. 

The truth will be shrouded in fog... But not if the Investigation Team is reaching out to the truth!

143870893.review:
I lived in Japan for almost 14 years, and my wife is from a nondescript small town in Aichi that bears a strong resemblance to Inaba - where this story takes place.  So keep in mind the nostalgia factor is off the charts here for me.  That said, even if you don't know anything about Japan, I think you would likely still enjoy Persona 4, one of the best RPGs ever made.  My thoughts:

The good:
The story is excellent. It's a supernatural murder mystery and coming-of-age tale set in a small town in Japan. You play a high school student and you must make friends, juggle studies and part-time jobs...and  fight demons in an alternate dimension. To say anymore would be to ruin the thrill of discovery.  Great mix of comedy, horror, teen drama and fantasy.

The characters are insanely likable, and their dialog is frequently hilarious and occasionally heartwarming. There is a heavy emphasis on creating a network of friends - as well as some light dating sim aspects.  And the social links you make improve your combat abilities too in the more fantastical battles that inevitably occur. Also, the teachers you get are consistently funny (and realistic) in their obsessions and inappropriate comments in and out of class.

The design work for character portraits and monsters is all top-notch.  Of course the surreal demons and demigods present here as the MOBs and Personae are mostly recycled from previous Shin Megami Tensei and Persona games, so no need to reinvent the wheel.  But aesthetically, this is a fantastic game.

The gameplay loop is a mix of life sim and dungeon crawling, and it is hyperaddictive.  Combat is turn-based but extremely dynamic and colorful.  There is also a Pokemon-like mechanic in which you collect and/or combine your 'pets' in cool and unpredictable ways.

The OST is a bop, and the anime cut-scenes by Madhouse are great. Oh, and the voice acting is tremendous (at least on the Japanese side, I can't speak for the English dub).

The meh:
Though character portraits are in gorgeous manga-style, the actual characters are showing their age a bit - a very Wii-U look to them overall.  And though the aesthetic of the backgrounds is spot on stylistically, there's not a lot of realism. That might bother some who have came from Persona 5 or other more recent SMT games.

Without going into spoiler territory, there are multiple endings and the 'best' one apparently involves an entirely unnecessary secret boss. I avoided it, and regret nothing, as I was very happy to finish my 68 hour runthrough where I did.  

It is a bit of a slow burn starting out, and the unofficial tutorial section at the start lasts a really long time.

If you don't like occasionally over-the-top anime style slapstick comedy, some story beats may be a little cringy for you.

Some of the side-quests can be a little low effort (i.e. go into the dungeon and find this thing for me).

If you're into dungeons that really challenge your brain full of intricate puzzles, you might be disappointed. From my perspective, though, having just finished SMT Nocturne, I was glad not to have the arbitrary trial and error nonsense puzzling of that game.

I'm not a fan of fishing mini-games in most RPGs, and admittedly P4G did not do much to win me over to the sweaty angler mindset.

The bad:
There is not a scrap of "bad" in this thing.

The verdict:
Persona 4 is full of contradictions.  It's wholesome yet bawdy.  Heartwarming and horrific.  Dark yet ultimately optimistic. I am now super-hyped to be saddling up for 5...

143737319.review:
It took me about 71hrs to play through until New Years and finish what I assume to be the majority of the game.  There was more time to tighten up all my bonds with my companions and max out all of my Social Links and to eventually fight some big nasty boss but I decided to put the game down and step back.  My knee-jerk reaction is that Persona 4 Golden is one of the best RPGs I've played in the last few years.  I have never played any other Persona game or Shin Megami Tensei game.  I enjoyed the feeling of autonomy you get when controlling your character's actions within the time-blocks.  You essentially get one full school year broken up into after school and night time time-segments to pursue friendships, romantic relationships, folding cranes, translating things, or even part-time jobs like working in a hospital.  And all of your choices contribute to the overall story and make your character unique in his experience and interactions.

It felt a little drawn out with how many times we have to dive back into the TV to save people over and over and over again.  And there's 10 floors of randomly generated mobs and hazards with no save points so you have to goho-me and save each time and then restart from the 5th or 6th floor - depending on how far you got.

I loved the story!  It's a teenaged-murder mystery that really engages its audience and makes you feel like you're in control of solving the murders.  The music was fantastic and the characters are unique and loveable and really heartwarming.  I'd highly recommend this game to anyone who is a fan of JRPGs or Final Fantasy RPGs or just turn-based tactical RPGs in general.  The combat was a lot of fun and they make the rock-paper-scissor mechanic go very far.  It gets a little old but it's well-done and entertaining!

Absolutely amazing game. Persona 5 Royal was my introduction to the franchise, but I enjoyed this game even more, which was not what I was expecting.

If you compare it to P5R on the surface level, the gameplay seems inferior. Dungeons are procedurally generated (like Mementos), there's no baton pass, no gun skills, and the battle UI isn't as nice. That might sound bad, but I got used to it after a few floors in the first dungeon, and it ultimately didn't affect my enjoyment of the game. On the plus side, this game didn't have any bs bosses (*cough* Okumura *cough*). Although, I do prefer the Shuffle Time mechanic in this game to shadow negotiation in P5. Obtaining new Personas is no longer a guessing game, and trying to get sweep bonuses at every opportunity is kind of addicting.

The graphics are also significantly inferior to P5R, but that's just because the base game was released on the PS2, which is more than two decades old at this point. Again, it didn't affect my enjoyment of the game.

What really sold this game for me was the story, more specifically, the setting and characters. Inaba is the perfect setting for this game. The small town environment allows the characters to more easily develop bonds with each other in a way that feels genuine and organic. I really enjoyed all of the social links in this game and overall prefer them to those in P5.

Also, the soundtrack. P5 set the bar extremely high, so I thought it couldn't get any better. But it did. The only thing is that it's not as extensive as P5's, so it's not as varied. I swear, "Like a dream come true" plays for at least a quarter of the scenes in the game.

My only real complaint about this game? It ends.

143196377.review:
I would recommend this game to big fans of Persona and/or turn-based JRPGs. I, as a person, am not drawn towards turn-based games and started P4Golden because of my incredibly positive experience in P5Royal. Overall, I really enjoyed the characters and story, but had a below average experience with the combat.

  The combat in P4Golden I would describe as being a participant in a japanese game show where most of the time they just fuck with the contestant then play the funny noise whenever they get flustered.
  A lot of the in-game combat encounters just left me annoyed with enemies with funny quirks as being heavily damage resistant to their own weaknesses, being resistant to literally everything, severely reducing damage taken from all-out-attacks, and having other enemies/themselves cast protection magic that block the only normal way of actually fighting them.

  As for the characters, comparatively with my experience with the P5Royal cast, I found all the characters to be just as good, or better than the P5Royal cast as a result of being a little more well-rounded, except for the sidekick character, oh my god.
  The story at times feels like going through the motions but often enough asks for the player to engage with it to keep me from losing interest.

  In spite of my complaints, I feel I had an overall good experience with this game but feel like it might not be the best entry point for the series for anyone not into turn-based combat.

I look forward to the release of Persona 3 Reload for my first experience with P3, partially because I've been told the version ported to steam is an inferior version of the game. Hopefully if that does well then there could be the possibility of a P4 remake of sorts to bring the game up to the quality to allow it to be just a fine entry point as P5 was.

143057003.review:
Persona 4 Golden - A Transformative Journey into the Heart

Introduction:

Where do I even begin with Persona 4 Golden? This game is an absolute masterpiece that has left an indelible mark on my heart and soul. From the moment I first set foot in the fictional town of Inaba, I knew I was in for something extraordinary. Little did I realize that this immersive and emotionally charged experience would not only become my favorite game but also a reflection of my personal growth.

A Captivating Story:
At its core, Persona 4 Golden is a captivating murder mystery wrapped in a high school simulator with supernatural elements. The narrative centers around a group of endearing characters who band together to investigate a series of mysterious murders plaguing the sleepy town of Inaba. As the protagonist, I was not merely a spectator; I was an active participant in shaping the outcome of this enthralling tale. The storytelling is gripping, seamlessly weaving themes of friendship, self-discovery, identity, and the shadows within us all.

The Power of Bonds:
The game brilliantly showcases the power of human connections. The bonds forged with the diverse cast of characters are at the heart of Persona 4 Golden's charm. Each character is so richly developed, with their struggles and insecurities, making them feel like real individuals. Through meaningful interactions, I learned valuable life lessons, empathy, and the importance of supporting one another during times of adversity. Witnessing these relationships evolve and grow was both heartwarming and emotionally impactful.

The Persona Fusion:
The gameplay mechanics are a brilliant blend of traditional turn-based combat and social simulation. The concept of "Personas" - manifestations of one's inner self - added depth to the battles and allowed for strategic planning. The thrill of collecting, fusing, and experimenting with different Personas was immensely satisfying, encouraging me to explore different playstyles and discover my strengths.

A Living, Breathing World:
Inaba felt like a real place. The attention to detail in the world-building, the NPCs with their daily routines, and the seasonal changes contributed to the game's immersive nature. I enjoyed strolling through the shopping district, working part-time jobs, and establishing bonds with fellow students. It's rare to find a game that captures the essence of living in a small town so beautifully.

Emotional Soundtrack:
Shoji Meguro's masterful compositions provided the perfect emotional backdrop for the entire experience. From upbeat battle themes to melancholic melodies, the music added another layer of depth to the game's storytelling. Even now, certain tracks evoke strong emotions and transport me back to my time in Inaba.

Impact on My Life:
Persona 4 Golden isn't just a game; it's a reflection of my personal growth. Through the characters' struggles and triumphs, I found solace in my journey of self-discovery. It taught me to confront my inner demons, accept myself for who I am, and cherish the friendships that make life meaningful. The game served as a beacon of hope during challenging times, reminding me that even in the darkest of days, there's always light waiting to be found.

Conclusion:

Persona 4 Golden is an extraordinary RPG that has etched a permanent place in my heart. It represents the epitome of what gaming can achieve as an art form, blending captivating storytelling, deep gameplay mechanics, and a profound emotional impact. This game taught me the value of friendship, self-acceptance, and the beauty of forging bonds with others. To me, Persona 4 Golden is not just a game; it's a life-changing experience that will forever hold a special place in my heart.

143042485.review:
I knew this game was famous for it's social sim aspect, but i never imagined it would hit this close to the home and leave such an emotional impact.

I finished the game within 2 weeks, every day of which i logged in i felt genuine excitement.

Every play session felt like spending time with friends. Whom you grow closer, form and cherish those bonds. However, as the game eventually ends it feels like actually breaking up with them, losing them, hence the post-persona depression.

[h1] Pros: [/h1] 

[b]* Main cast of characters;[/b] Their self discovery, bonding, banter, visual design, an actually very good english dub. 
 
[b]* Catchy soundtracks;[/b] Your Affection, Heartbeat Heartbreak, Heaven, Who's There, The Almighty, The Fog.

[b]* Bright and colorful visual art style;[/b] Apart from the character designs, 2D assets, UI, transition edits, use of color.

[b]* Late 2000's nostalgia;[/b] CRT TV's, Flip Phones, great vegetables.

[b]* Tone;[/b] Energetic and joyful mood contrasting with healthy dose of 'foggy' murder mystery. Aka putting "Who's There" abruptly after a cheery music.

[b]* Naoto[/b]

[h1] Cons: [/h1]

[b]*🤚🏻DUN🤚🏻 🤚🏻GEON🤚🏻  🤚🏻CRAW🤚🏻 🤚🏻LING🤚🏻;[/b] Quickly becomes repetitive and tedious. It constantly requires reclearing and grinding to reach certain character levels, as bosses often outlevel you. While some dungeons offer respite with good music, I found myself try skipping encounters and solely focusing on defeating the Goldhands most of the time.

[b]* Goldhands;[/b] whoever thought placing them near chests with hidden monsters in it near the end of corridors was a good idea, should just be shoved into the nearest TV.

[b]* Triggers;[/b] for unlocking some dungeons, social links, romance options, and even endings are confusing and questionable, to say the least. Backtracking, waiting a day, talking to random NPCs with no apparent relation, and head-scratching dialogue choices are involved in some.

Without spoiling, two triggers that pissed me the most are

1. "I am glad you are a girl."

2. Game itself openly tells you to go somewhere which can cause you to miss "True" ending if you do that.

[b]* JRPG Tropefest;[/b] while common in JRPG's especially considering this game's target audience beign teenagers, it's infested with tropes, the way themes are served and directly told through heavy-handed metaphors feels anime-like and juvenile, which is a bit shame. Because searching for truth through hardships, even when it hurts, only then you can better your condition is a timeless theme, but it gets swept under the rug due to this approach.


[b]* They done dirty to Yosuke;[/b] started as your go to "Best Buddy," acted almost like a protagonist, making most of the plans and deductions, being the MVP guy in the beginning. But later on, he went full on comedy relief, at times cracking offensive jokes and doing creepy stuff out of nowhere that makes you go, [i]"Dude, what the hell? Why?"[/i]

143002656.review:
*Hours on record so high because I fell asleep and left it open too many times to count, actual time count around 95-100 hours*

I wouldn't recommend it solely cause the dialogue REEKS of the late 2000's and being homophobic is often a punchline because "haha gay" is funny. It's taxing over a journey that takes around 80-100 hours depending how much you want to complete the game. 

Aside from that the game suffers from pacing issues like crazy, bouncing between serious murder mystery and "let's fuck around and throw a concert" and other such distractions. It's hard to get engaged in the plot when the game itself doesn't seem that interested in the plot, and drags it's heels with telling it. It's also a murder mystery where you can never really solve the TRUE mystery at hand, or even really discern the killer from the information the games gives you on your own (not to mention the wrench that the post-game content throws into your ability to figure out the killer). One of the "Bad Endings" of the games called the Accomplice Ending by fans that shows a very interesting what-if scenario, but the actual plot itself is lackluster. When it actually stays on track it feels very repetitive, of the same order of events happening with only a few changes. The game also chickens out so many times of there being dire consequences to dire situations, such as characters dying. It feels cheap and completely removes the idea that anything bad is actually going to happen. 

The characters, like the plot, are another instance of a lot of potential wasted. So many of the main cast have interesting stories that their social links/general dialogue bring up but never resolve in an interesting or meaningful way.  Yosuke is especially homophobic/disparaging to non-traditionally male activities/hobbies or being perceived as not straight or into women and eager to prove he's a "real man", something the other male characters are not, and that is never resolved or explained. Many see him as a closeted gay character and while that makes sense as homosexual men tend to have a drive to be perceived as straight to avoid ridicule, the game never confirms this or even really hints towards it, so it exists solely in fan-cannon.  Basically all the characters like this example feel incomplete and don't do anything with the interesting premises of these characters, such as Naoto's gender/gender expression, Yukiko's family expectations, Rise and the model/idol industry in Japan/Asia as a whole. I enjoyed Kanji's character the most as he's just a dude who's comfortable with himself and learns to deal with his anger issues, I especially enjoy this character because he's into very non-traditionally masculine activities like knitting and when people point that out he's like "so?" I love the confidence. Chie has absolutely zero character but she's funny, Teddy is god awful, I hate his voice and all the words that come out of his mouth, Dojima has an interesting story exploring grief/guilt and single parenthood that I thought was the most interesting in the game, and Nanako is just adorable and sweet, always upbeat and positive and the way she bonds with the MC is very cute. Her resiliency in the face of a difficult upbringing is admirable and she serves as a great foil to Dojima's character. 

Gameplay wise this game is great, incredibly similar to P3, but native party control which you only get in P3P is very nice. If you've played any persona game before it's nothing you haven't seen before. The UI is the same as P3 but yellow/gold instead of blue, so the game is easy to navigate. You can pretty easily get through this game on normal mode without excessive grinding, and there are no unfair or sharp difficulty spikes, with the exception of one boss towards the late parts of the mid-game that feels quite a bit harder than it should be, the early parts of the game being the hardest. In typical JRPG fashion, late game bosses are HP tanks, and will take a little while but are overall manageable. If you want to break the game or optimize, Shuffle Time is incredibly easy to break and become especially overpowered.

The music is the exceptionally good, and a highlight though it could do with more tracks, some get repetitive by the end.
