142774450.review:
JP voice acting combined the Community Enhancement Pack mod was enough reason to give this classic another go. There have been plenty arguments written by many before about P4 v P5 (and P3) comparisons, such as better cast chemistry in P4, much better QoL features in P5 (which the mod helped alleviate somewhat), massive upgrade in dungeon design in P5, way more things to do in P5, and many other points favoring P5. Understandably, these points are expected improvements given the fact that it is a newer installment to the franchise, so I'd like to shift focus into the more timeless aspects of these titles:

Persona's plot writing has never been its party piece, and it's no different in Persona 4. It's decent, shortly put. But what Persona consistently delivers is its message, a commentary of society's flaws, using concepts derived from Jungian psychology as its medium to deliver that message, while also doubling as the device to break through the latches of those flaws. Examining P4 and P5 closer, P5 takes an approach of antagonizing individuals that have negatively affected one of the party members, while also representing one of the seven deadly sins on the side. In P4's case, the antagonists are[spoiler]themselves, i.e. each of the party members, in fighting an alter ego shaped by the individual's incompatibility with society[/spoiler]. I find P4's ideas to be far more interesting than what is being done in P5, taking a more introspective look into the problems of society, which I appreciate better than identifying "bad seeds" in society and taking them out. In a more practical sense, P4's approach facilitates an easy way to add depth, development, and dimension to the party members, whom you will be interacting with for the entire game.

What makes P4 outstanding to me however, is not this inwards-looking approach to solve problems mentioned above per se, but its ability to continuously reinforce the themes that make up P4. This idea of "thematic coherence" is something that I am particularly fond of when I examine works, and I think P4 is one of them that excels in this regard. The idea of "incompatibilities with society" is turned into conflict points in the main plot, resolved with them accepting their weaknesses, and this is then further expanded in the party member's S.Links as they try to overcome those said weaknesses. The narrative likes to emphasize the importance of your bonds, as it is the norm with Persona titles. But P4 feels particularly on-the-nose about this, as I recall a certain scene in early December where the narration drives this point home after reading text messages from concerned friends shortly after a tragedy. This coherence runs through the finer details as well: P4 sets up a very thematically matching final boss, and is the only one that manages to fit in a quick course on the mythology behind the main persona (Izanagi) and the definition of Persona and Shadow according to Jungian psychology (The extra Classroom TV episodes are very informative and fascinating, I highly recommend giving it a read to anyone who's interested in psychology).

In short, the thematic coherence in P4 is the strongest among the three, setting it apart from the other titles.

I would like to praise the great localization work Atlus has done for the Persona titles as a final note. One full playthrough in JP gave me direct confirmation of the quality of translation and voice acting work in place of the source material. Though there are some EN voices that irritate me to no end (Chie), the quality is far better than many subpar dubs I've heard in other works. Here's my opinion of which version of the cast's voices I prefer, to conclude this piece:

-Yosuke: EN > JP
-Chie: JP > EN
-Yukiko: JP >= EN
-Kanji: EN > JP
-Rise: EN > JP
-Teddie: EN > JP
-Naoto: JP >= EN
-Nanako: JP > EN
-Dojima: JP = EN

142530254.review:
"You ever hear of the Midnight Channel? You're supposed to look into a TV that's switched off, alone, exactly at midnight on a rainy night. While you're staring at your own image, another person will appear on the screen and they say that person's your soulmate."

Your protagonist recently moved to Inaba, a small town. Some rumors around town about something called the Midnight Channel. If you turn off the TV at midnight when it's raining outside, you'll see your soulmate appear on the screen. At the same time, you and your friends are getting involved in mysterious murders that could be related to Midnight Channel. The story switches between comic and drama moments perfectly. One of the most memorable things in Persona is the characters, the unforgettable cast of characters in this game that makes you want to complete all their social links and other events with them.

The gameplay is similar to Persona 3 but improved, more fast and fun. Dungeons are good, it's easy to level up and there are more ways to raise your social link fast. The OST is impeccable as expect

Even after those years, Persona 4 Golden still is a solid enjoyable title. Worth it.

142480278.review:
Persona 4 as a game is fantastic. Great system, great atmosphere, great story line, great music.

The murder mystery is well developed. Each story beat makes you want to know more. Most of the characters are fun to know. Several of them have really deep emotional impacts, especially Nanako.

Why then would I not recommend it?

Homophobia.

In the middle of the story the game delved into full-blown homophobia without either resolving it or questioning it. All the nuances about two different characters' sexuality and gender identity went down the drain for cheap comic reliefs. The writing was disturbing, disappointing and hurtful.

I want to clarify that I don't want to pin this to the in-game characters, but the writer of the game. I get that they wanted to convey immaturity of the adolescence, while trying to be funny. But this is done at the expense of queer identity, at the expense of a topic that needed sensitivity, especially in East Asia. It's "funny" to the perceived player base, because the writers never considered how these homophobic scenes would impact queer players, who in real life have probably dealt with similar frustrating situations. Queer players remained outsiders for the writers of the game.

If you find it a minor issue, or even a non-issue, good for you. Please enjoy the game. But I wish to convey how much of this attitude of poking fun at the queer identity has negatively colored the game for me. Thanks for reading.

142445932.review:
After completing this game on both Nintendo Switch and now on PC, I can now say this is one of, if not THE best J-RPG I've ever played, thus far. It's the most comedy-driven of the 3 available Persona games (3P-5R), while still maintaining an intriguing murder mystery plot. A very small (and kind of optional) portion of the content added in Golden may be a drag, but with that aside, the additions are pretty decent. It also streamlined the battle system, in comparison to 3, which made it a bit more complicated than it should've been (which 5 improved upon). The soundtrack of this game is also pretty good, and worth the 30$ I spent to own it on CD. Tracks like Long Way (Magatsu Inaba/Mandala), SNOWFLAKES, Your Affection, and Reach Out to the Truth are worth a listen, on their own. The cast (the Investigation Team) also feels like it has a better dynamic, in comparison to 5's Phantom Thieves, in which everyone in the Investigation Team feels like they're all friends with each other, compared to the Phantom Thieves, in which all the members (excluding maybe a few) are just mutually friends with Joker. The social links are also very interesting, like Rise's, in which she deals with leaving showbiz, Yukiko not wanting to inherit her inn (and coming to terms with it), Yosuke's grief over Saki, Dojima trying to connect with his daughter (while also trying to solve the unsolved case regarding his late wife), etc.

As for the negatives, there were some, like Marie's (optional, unless you want the true ending) dungeon, how long Shadow Mitsuo's boss fight drags out for a bit too long, and how generic the battle UI was, in-between 3's revolver based UI and 5's clean (and streamlined) UI. Those 3 aside, I can't remember that many other bones I had to pick, that aren't really divisive.

This game was an overall fun experience and a roller coaster of emotions and comedy, which I enjoyed, the whole way through. I loved about all this game had to offer, till the very end.

142286169.review:
Persona 4 Golden is an absolute masterpiece and a shining example of what a JRPG can accomplish. This game had me completely captivated from start to finish, and it's an experience that I will cherish for a long time.

First and foremost, the story of Persona 4 Golden is compelling and expertly crafted. It revolves around a group of high school students investigating a series of mysterious murders in a rural town. The blend of supernatural elements with real-world issues creates a unique and immersive narrative that kept me hooked throughout the entire game. The characters are well-developed and have their own personal struggles, making them relatable and endearing. The bonds you forge with them feel genuine and have a profound impact on the overall story.

The gameplay mechanics in Persona 4 Golden are deep and addictive. The core of the game revolves around balancing your school life, social interactions, and dungeon exploration. During the day, you attend classes, build relationships with your classmates, and explore the town. At night, you dive into the TV World, a dungeon filled with shadows, where you engage in turn-based battles. The combat system is strategic and satisfying, allowing you to exploit enemy weaknesses and unleash devastating attacks. The Persona fusion system, which lets you combine and create new Personas, adds an extra layer of depth and customization.

One of the standout aspects of Persona 4 Golden is its incredible soundtrack. The music perfectly complements the game's atmosphere and enhances every moment. Whether it's the catchy battle themes or the poignant melodies during emotional scenes, the soundtrack is simply outstanding.

The graphics and art style in Persona 4 Golden may not be cutting-edge by today's standards, but they have a unique charm that still holds up well. The character designs are vibrant and memorable, and the animated cutscenes are a visual treat. The game's visual presentation helps create a distinct and cohesive world that pulls you in.

142254272.review:
This is a very personal review but I came across "Persona 4" years ago through let's play videos so I know some plot points already. I was very intrigued about the concept of facing your Shadows of the story. I thought "This seems like a game I would really like, I'll buy it when I have money from having a job as a responsible adult".
Fast forward to March 2023, I was pretty stressed out. My grandmother just passed away, my crush rejected me for the Nth time and I still couldn't overcome my crippling anxiety to get a job. I was on the verge of a breakdown. For some reason, I was reminded of this game. So I bought a game for the first time.
Maybe it was because I had been spoiled but I won't lie the main story wasn't a masterpiece or anything. For a murder mystery, it was heavily bogged down by copious amount of slice-of-life scenes. BUT those ARE what made P4 truly shines. It's the wacky but endearing characters that you spend time talking to.
The cozy small town setting that you can run around just singing along to the catchy BGM.
The ability to do so many things at your own pace (which can be daunting at first but you'll get used to it).
The combat, eh that one could be better. Not really a fan of the auto-generated dungeons, it's a bit grindy. I'm not great at strategy games either for the hard battles and fusing mechanics. But if that's your thing, you do you! :D

--- Spoilers about some social links ---
As I hanged out to talk to:
+ Grandma Death about [spoiler] dementia [/spoiler]
+ Ai about her [spoiler] inability to love herself [/spoiler]
+ Naoto about [spoiler] not being afraid to change [/spoiler]
+ Nanako about her [spoiler] loneliness [/spoiler]
+ Rise and Teddie about [spoiler] not knowing who they are [/spoiler]
+ Yosuke about his [spoiler] unfulfilled feelings towards his crush [/spoiler]
+ Kanji about [spoiler] wanting to be accepted for who he is [/spoiler]
+ Naoki about [spoiler] processing his grief [/spoiler]
I felt I was indirectly comforting myself. I suppose in the end, I can't say that Persona 4 makes me a better person. But it was there for me when I needed it. The 2 months I spent playing this game to hang out with these fictional friends and family was precious. Thank you Persona 4 Golden. Here's to hoping I can one day afford to play P5R too. (I'm waiting to play the P3R remake before P3P).

P.S: I have recently started learning piano [spoiler] like Nanako at the epilogue [/spoiler]. Not exactly because of her, but I guess it's just one of those things where life slowly warms you up to an idea overtime.
P.P.S: Naoto and Ai are my top girls, but ultimately I have to choose Naoto as my bae. Ai should still need more time to grow.

142190652.review:
Best story I’ve ever played among both the SMT and Persona series, the country life literally touched me more than the metropolitan life in Persona 5. As the stage of the whole case, the *Yasoinabashi* town owns the same weird but warm vibe as the *Twin Peak town* which is known as the classical TV series by David Lynch and it’s more possibly a tribute to this show. The story began with a murder case same as the show, and this classical theme seems always fascinating. 

P4G added a weather system to replace the moon phase system in P3 as the key to promoting the plot. The innovative settings of midnight TV and fog made the story more strange but interesting. Its essence is to reflect people's desire to peek into the inner world of a specific character and will parody the way to produce people's thoughts about the character's character style and ambiguous scenes. The character's appearance on midnight TV was sharply different from the real world.

The music was also in charge of Shōji same as P3. The original soundtrack of the Golden edition adds a lot of new tracks based on the ’08 album, especially the tracks of fight and hang out made me love so bad.

These lifeful characters constitute the core part of the whole story without a doubt, the daily, affection, and community parts were the funniest for me as the tradition of the Persona series. It seems to me that Chie is the best girl among all the kids and she made me feel relaxed and funny every time I get along with her.

As the enhanced edition of the ’08 game first sold on PS2, besides the quirky twist story and all distinctive characters, the actual graphics are obviously out of step with the current trends and the action of characters sometimes looks slightly awkward, but this nostalgic vibe precisely fits the story optimally.

141817890.review:
TLDR: Persona 4 Golden is a good JRPG, but it certainly has flaws. The best entry point into Persona as a franchise, but definitely not the best Persona game.

General thoughts: Persona 4 Golden is good game, its a good Persona game, but it's dramatically over-hyped. I enjoyed my time with persona 4, but i found it considerably lacking compared to its successor. If you're like me, you're here because you heard a lot of people say its the best entry in the entire series; its not. Despite having a main character and important side character voiced by Ichigo Kurosaki/ Lelouch Vi Britannia, i found the game lacking in a lot of the personality and flair that other persona games have. Lets talk about it.

Gameplay:
Persona 4's gameplay is classic SMT gameplay. 4 member party, turned based, elemental weaknesses, and a 1-more system. Enjoyable, fairly easy, and familiar if you've played a party-based RPG before. The gameplay is nothing special though, and becomes exceptionally repetitive after your 3rd or 4th dungeon.

The social link system is also present, and that is executed very well in Persona 4. The bonds are well done, with some feeling awfully rushed towards their highest ranks, but otherwise provide good characterization and gameplay benefits (though not on the level of Persona 5's confidant system). Coming to 4 after playing 5 will make you hunger for a bit more.

Minigames are here too, with fishing being the one you'll likely engage in the most as well as bug catching and farming. You will want to rip your ears out after hearing "Great Vegetables" for the 100th time though.

Lastly, there are no save-points in the actual dungeons themselves. An inconvenience that can be fixed if you're willing to mod the game, though.

Graphics:
This is a game from 2008, it looks like its from 2008. Not ugly, but certainly dated.

Audio:
Normally a strong-point for Persona games, I genuinely dislike most of Persona 4's soundtrack. It is super pop-heavy, and the higher tones that are generally present throughout gave me ear fatigue. That said, there are of course a few exceptional tracks here. Studio Backlot and Heaven come to mind. I found the battle themes lacking and the same can be said for the overworld tracks as well, Snowflakes being the lone exception the that trend.

Audience:
Well, there's a lot of provocative stuff in this game so i'd say if you're not 18 or older you should get your parent's permission. Rise's dungeon, particularly that boss fight is..... sensual. 18+ for sure.

Difficulty:
Persona 4 is not a hard game, but it does require a bit of grinding. Fairly easy overall, especially once you get the hang of party composition and managing your own personas.

Story:
Persona 4 tells a great story, but the true ending is kind of out of left field. I'm trying to keep this review as spoiler free as possible, so I won't go into many details. The story is well written, good characters and villains, but just... a kinda random true ending.

Characters:
The selling point for any Persona game is the cast of characters. For this section, I will refer to the characters by their Arcana to avoid spoilers. There are a few great characters here, like the Emperor and Fortune characters in particular. I do find some characters overly annoying, however, like the Lovers and Star characters. Star in particular has voice acting that is painful for me to listen to. Chariot is hit or miss as is Magician. Some of their social link stories are also very well done, Moon in particular has an incredibly satisfying development.

If that made no sense to you, characters that you form bonds with are classified by an "Arcana" and having a persona of that "Arcana" or type when interacting with them yields more progress towards your bond. The higher a bond level, the more powerful the personas of that type you can create.

Gametime:
It took me roughly 60 hours to 100% this game, but I was moving at a lightning pace. If you're unfamiliar with this game, 60 hours is probably the runtime for a full playthrough. It has replayability in the sense of an added super-boss and a standard NG+ identity.

Comparison to Persona 5 Royal:
Seeing as Persona 5 Royal is the most popular Persona game, I'm writing this section for people who have played Persona 5 and are considering Persona 4. A few major differences to note here. The combat in Persona 4 feels much less dynamic. There are no technicals, there are no baton passes, and there is no mid-battle party shuffling.

Personally, i think Persona 5's cast is also better. Don't get me wrong, Persona 4 has Ichigo/Lelouch as a main character with Rei Ayanami, Spiderman, Rakshata Chawla/Chun-Li, Phoenix Wright, and Batman/Pagan Min as the other main voice actors but their development feels uneven. Persona 5 suffers a similar problem with some of its characters as well, but those felt like the exception while rushed character development feels like the norm in Persona 4.

The biggest difference for me though is the quality of the soundtracks. I know music is by far the most subjective thing in this review, but Persona 5's jazz theme accentuated by the game's striking visuals made it feel like it had so much more character than Persona 4. Inaba is a great setting, but I think not having any of the vendors be confidants/social links made the city feel more distant than it should have considering it's meant to have a small-town vibe and yet i felt more connected to Tokyo in P5.

Persona 5 is a better game than Persona 4 is, and Persona 5 certainly has better final bosses than 4.

I'd recommend grabbing this on sale for $15 or cheaper if you're interested, its a good game. Just not great. 7.5/10

141663674.review:
This game is old, this game is really old as fuck... but I still like it a lot.

Just for comparison Persona 4 was first released in 2008, it was around the year we saw the release of games like Okami/Final Fantasy 12 and movies like Babel/Rocky Balboa/A Scanner Darkly, almost the same year when Radiohead's "In Rainbows" album hit the internet. The game was intended to depict modern life in 2008 so everywhere you go the TVs are those old-school heavy CRT models. It may not have been the original intention, but playing it now in 2023 lends it a certain retro vibe... not because it's trying to be retro but because it genuinely reflected the times when it was first released.

It's been fun to revisit and experience for the first time all the new "Golden" content. The game flows better now, with many changes to the combat balance, a bunch of new features like special attacks, personas, skills, and many special events we didn't have originally. 

But i'm over 130h of gametime... holy shit that's a lot.

141567944.review:
Persona 4 Golden is a masterpiece that weaves a warmhearted and unforgettable story, making it an absolute gem of classic RPG. From the moment you step into the shoes of the protagonist and arrive in the rural town of Inaba, you're swept away by a tale that touches the depths of friendship, self-discovery, and the power of human connection.

The game's narrative shines with its engaging characters, each with their own distinct personalities and struggles. As you form bonds and build relationships with them, you'll witness their personal growth and overcome challenges together. The heartwarming moments, genuine friendships, and the deep emotional connection forged with the cast make Persona 4 Golden a truly special experience.

Beyond its captivating story, the gameplay mechanics are finely crafted. The fusion of traditional turn-based combat with the unique Persona system allows for strategic battles, where you can summon powerful personas to unleash devastating attacks. Additionally, the Social Link system provides an opportunity to spend time with your friends, deepening your bonds and unlocking new abilities in battle.

Persona 4 Golden's visuals are vibrant and charming, reflecting the cozy and idyllic small-town atmosphere. The soundtrack is an absolute delight, with catchy tunes that perfectly capture the game's mood and enhance its emotional impact. The game tackles mature themes and tackles them with sensitivity, making you care deeply about the characters and their personal struggles. It's a testament to the power of storytelling and how it can resonate with players on a profound level.

In conclusion, Persona 4 Golden is an exceptional game that excels in its warmhearted storytelling, captivating gameplay, and memorable characters. Its ability to evoke emotions, foster deep connections, and explore meaningful themes make it an experience that will stay with you long after the credits roll. If you're seeking an RPG that combines engaging gameplay with a heartfelt narrative, Persona 4 Golden is the peak of PERSONA series.

141557376.review:
A very strong JRPG, set in a small town beset by mysterious murders. The persona series is renowned for its extremely good story telling, and Persona 4 is probably the best of bunch in this regard. The game does suffer from a dated combat system and more grind than you would expect to find in a modern game. However, the later problem can be solved with the provided difficulty options (I recommend setting the difficulty hard, but also giving yourself bonus XP and money). The combat system is a bit of a drag, although it is certainly passable rather than bad, and the story you experience along the way more than make up for it. 

I would say that if you have never played a Persona game before you should certainly get 5 before 4, as that offers a much more well rounded experience, but 4 is an extremely good game should you find yourself wanting more. I also found that a controller was almost essential, as the game was quite tricky to play on a mouse and keyboard. These two notes aside, I would strongly recommend picking up this game, especially when it is on sale

141548366.review: A masterclass of story and character development. I could not have asked for a better intro into a beloved series and I now understand why Persona is held in such high regard. 141238811.review:
[h1]-Persona 4 Golden Long Review-[/h1]


Before getting into the positive, here’s what you don’t hear about Persona 4 Golden: 

The game has some of the most boring dungeons that I have completed, to classify it as “absolutely soporific dungeon design” would be an understatement. Enemy repetition is also a problem, by the time you are on the last third of the game you will be tired of seeing the same enemies over and over again. 

The battle music, while great and catchy at first, also gets tiring due to hay many times you are going to hear the same few loud vocal themes over and over again throughout the game.

And finally, there are some problems when it comes to balancing, with some weird difficulty spikes in the middle of the game that force you to grind and an ending stretch that is way too easy with how overpowered you can get in those last few months of the game with minimal effort.

But while those are big problems for a lengthy jrpg, Persona 4 Golden not only has good qualities to balance this out but also has something that a lot of games lack: SOUL.

When it comes to its good qualities, the design of the UI is stylish, the music is fantastic (even though, as I said earlier they could have used more variety for the battle themes), the art direction and backgrounds are strong, and the combat system is solid.

But as I mentioned above, SOUL is what makes this game shine, and that soul is found in its story.

The plot is a well-written and satisfying mystery that constantly keeps you on edge with its many turns and revelations (especially in the last third of the game). 

The theme of truth is thoroughly explored, first delving deep into how the nature of society transforms reality, the media, repression, and identity and then masterfully tying all of those topics up by the end by reflecting on the desire and need for lies at the core of the human heart. And yet despite how fucking pretentious all of this sounds the messages delivered after exploring these topics feel honest and are presented in such a humble way that they come off as something beautiful.

And finally, its main characters are beyond excellent. The dynamics between characters as well as the group dynamic are fantastic, you could put these characters in any situation and it would be entertaining. Furthermore, all of them have lively personalities, are well fleshed out, feel rounded, and go through interesting and meaningful character arcs.

By the way congratulations to the English voice actors since they delivered some of the best performances that I have heard in a dub of a Japanese property.

The story as a whole has some incredible moments with all its elements working together to create heart-touching, powerful, memorable, cute, and meaningful scenes. Honestly, to see a story in any medium where you can feel that the writers are trying to convey and present something special is rare, but this is one of those stories.

To conclude, while its flaws aren’t easy to overlook, the positives way outnumber the negatives. In fact, the game story in particular has a unique charm of its own that makes it feel special, and while playing it you can see why so many have fallen in love with this entry in the franchise in particular and why it's a favorite game for so many. 

I definitely recommend it.


[h1]-Final score: 9,3-[/h1]

140667480.review:
Persona 4 is one of my all-time favorite RPGs. It has an excellent story with a mostly well-written cast, solid mechanical depth, and plenty of interplay between the time management simulation and the dungeon crawling. However, this particular version has changes from the PS2 original that I logged hundreds of hours in. There's an entirely new section of story gated off behind link progress on new characters, and your enjoyment of the game's final hours will largely hinge on how you like Marie and Adachi's links if you are a returning player, as well as the voice cast changes to Teddie and Chie. I personally greatly preferred the original Chie VA, so the new voice takes a lot of getting used to. Teddie's change is barely noticeable, however. 

I haven't personally played the endgame content, but I'm currently working on a new play-through and will be getting to those bits of the game soon. I'll update this review with further thoughts on that as soon as possible. But overall, if you want to get sold on RPGs as a genre, Persona 4 makes a persuasive argument for the genre as a whole.

Added note: I've been primarily playing on Steam Deck, and my experience has been overall quite stable, save for my Deck's personal quirk of randomly shutting off sometimes. Some art gets a bit jaggy looking in the distance at the deck's native resolution, like social link notification "!" boxes. But overall the game looks nice and plays perfectly fine on the Deck.

Que belleza de juego la verdad. Persona 4 Golden fue realmente una experiencia, voy a compararlo con el primer persona que jugué, el 3(Porque quiero.)
Es realmente bueno tecnicamente hablando, el pacing mejoró MUCHISIMO desde el 3, haciendo dungeons personalizadas. Amo el enfoque de que en vez de ser un grupo de amigos salvando el mundo (Un poco cliché) Sea un grupo de amigos resolviendo una serie de asesinatos en un pueblo remoto como lo es Inaba. 
9/10, le daria un 10, sin embargo, acá van razones por las cuales me gusta tanto y un par de cosas malas.
El pacing mejoró demasiado, si, las dungeons personalizadas son muy buenas, sin embargo, es horriblemente tedioso llegar a ellas. Por alguna razón, para algunas dungeons tienes que hacer una investigación antes, la cual permite al navegador de turno encontrar a la persona que buscan, esta investigación es horrible y bastante tediosa, lo cual también la hace aburrida. ¿Recomendado?, definitivamente, es muuy bueno, pero hay que tener mucho tiempo libre para poder disfrutarlo bien, y a decir verdad, unas pocas, muchas guias, parte del final verdadero lo consegui gracias a las mismas y a consejos de mi mejor amigo, pero bueno, 9/10, buenisimo.

140547957.review:
Desde el momento en que empiezas a jugar, te sumerges en un mundo lleno de misterio, amistad y autodescubrimiento. El juego te presenta a un grupo de adolescentes que se enfrentan a una serie de crímenes en una pequeña ciudad rural de Japón. La trama se desarrolla de manera brillante, manteniéndote intrigado y comprometido a medida que descubres los secretos ocultos detrás de los asesinatos.

Uno de los aspectos más destacados de Persona 4 Golden es su sistema de combate. Ofrece batallas por turnos estratégicas y desafiantes, permitiéndote utilizar los puntos fuertes y débiles de los diferentes personajes y enemigos para obtener ventaja. Además, la capacidad de invocar y fusionar a los Personas, que son criaturas que otorgan habilidades especiales a los protagonistas, añade una capa adicional de profundidad táctica.

Pero Persona 4 Golden no se limita solo al combate. Fuera de las batallas, tienes la oportunidad de explorar la ciudad, interactuar con una gran cantidad de personajes memorables y establecer lazos de amistad. Estas relaciones sociales son fundamentales para el desarrollo de la historia y tienen un impacto directo en el poder de tus Personas en la batalla. Es un sistema único que te impulsa a invertir tiempo y energía tanto en el mundo real como en el mundo de la TV.

Además de su cautivadora trama y sistema de juego, Persona 4 Golden también se destaca por su estilo visual y su banda sonora. El diseño artístico es vibrante y colorido, capturando perfectamente la atmósfera tanto de la ciudad como de los lugares sobrenaturales que explorarás. La música, por su parte, es variada y pegadiza, y acompaña a la perfección cada momento de la historia.

En resumen, Persona 4 Golden es un JRPG que ofrece una experiencia inolvidable. Con su historia profunda, personajes carismáticos, sistema de combate estratégico y elementos de simulación social, el juego logra mantenerte enganchado desde el principio hasta el final. Si eres fanático de los juegos de rol japoneses, Persona 4 Golden es una joya que no puedes dejar pasar.

140360402.review:
It's great.

Music as always is amazing, my fav track would be Heartbeat, Heartbreak.
Story is good. Main themes are truth and search for identity, I really liked how they were intertwined. Story being essentially a detective novel was cool, but it's pretty easy to get spoiled. Golden epilogue was really nice coming from P3.
Main cast is great. Dynamics greatly contribute to the lighter tone of the game and helps to build contrast for story climax. True culprit is a great character and villian.
Visuals are good. Overworld was kinda ruined by Golden because they broke a lot of visual effects, but TV World still looks great. Shared stylization with TV static and scanline effect is really cool. Dungeon visuals are good, Magatsu Inaba is especially great.
Overall gameplay is good. Game having party control and being balanced around it is good. Smaller gameplay improvements compared to P3 are all good.
Inaba as a setting was interesting. Refreshing change from urban setting of P3 and P5. Also liked commentary on japanese rural decay.
 
I didn't like mostly 2 things:
Dungeon "level design" sucks. I hated long hallways, tartarus generated floors were unironically better. And backtracking sucks too.
Hollow Forest gimmicks were annoying as fuck. Taking away your equipment on second to last dungeon was terrible.

140325004.review: My name is Tohru Adachi. I'm 27 years old. My apartment is in the northeast section of Inaba, where everything's all run down, and I am not married. I work as an officer for the Inaba Police Department, and I typically have to work long hours so I never get home on time. I don't smoke, but I occasionally drink. I'm up all night watching TV at least until midnight, and I never get a decent night's sleep, ever. After having a glass of lukewarm tap water and heartless browsing of Internet porn, I usually lie awake all night thinking of how much the world is shit. I wake up hating my life. I don't have time to see a doctor but I'm sure if I did he'd tell me I have all sorts of health issues. I'm trying to explain that I'm a person who wishes to live a very exciting life. I don't care how I interact with others, so I'm constantly losing, perpetuating the cycle. That is how I deal with society, and I know that is what brings me happiness. Although, if I were to fight I wouldn't lose to anyone.

Persona 4 Golden es sin dudas un juego.

Realmente se nota que los desarrolladores de Persona les gusta abarcar temáticas oscuras y adultas mezclandolas con inocencia e infantilismo como parte de su identidad visual.

Persona 4 Golden toca temas como la muerte, la percepción de uno mismo y lo que muestra a la sociedad, psicopatia, obsesión, y muchos topicos de machismo o homofobia en la sociedad actual.

El juego toma las bases de su antecesor y las expone en su máximo potencial, momentos donde el combate es agíl porque sabés reconocer las debilidades elementales de tus enemigos y otros combates más dificiles donde debés demostrar todos tus conocimientos aprendidos para poder avanzar en el juego.

La historia está muy buena, no cae en los clichés básicos de un policial, la trama te mantiene constantemente sacando teorias e ideas de quien puede ser el asesino que este detrás de todo esto, mientras te profundiza en los arcos de cada personaje a medida que vas desarrollando sus social links. 

Ademas del beneficio que obtenés por aumentar esos SL, te atrapa la trama que desarrolla cada personaje y como este evoluciona no solo a nivel narrativo sino en lo jugable, las personas de cada compañero son representaciones de su verdadero ser, y a medida que subes el social link de ese compañero y evoluciona como personaje también lo hace su persona, convirtiéndose en una versión superior al aceptar esos sesgos que se obliga a ocultar al mundo.

Realmente recomiendo Persona 4 Golden, es un muy buen juego en todos sentidos.

140139517.review:
My experience with Persona 4 Golden was nothing short of enchanting. It's rare to find a game that is able to combine an array of genres so skillfully, but this title does exactly that.

At its core, Persona 4 Golden is an RPG. But it also masterfully incorporates elements of life simulation and monster-battling games, making it a unique standout in the crowded gaming world. It's the perfect fusion of Japanese high school life and mystical dungeon crawling that makes Persona 4 Golden a distinct experience.

One of my favorite aspects of the game is the interesting blend of high school student life in Japan with the pokemon style stat raising. I enjoyed managing my time and choosing which activities to do each day, as well as building relationships with different characters. I also liked the fusion system that allows you to create new Personas by combining two or more existing ones. It was satisfying to experiment with different combinations and see what skills they inherited.

However, the game also has some drawbacks. One of them that is especially hard for me is that it can be very challenging to make choices, especially when they have consequences for the story and the relationships. Sometimes I felt overwhelmed by the options and the pressure to do everything right. I had to plan carefully and save often, otherwise I might miss out on some events or endings.

Overall, Persona 4 Golden is one of my favorite games. It has a unique and interesting blend of genres and themes that kept me engaged and entertained for hours. I would recommend it to anyone who likes RPGs, mystery, and slice-of-life.

Persona is by far the most popular JRPG series that even non-anime fans will still enjoy. 

The most common genres of game people dislike are JRPG's, turn based combat and anime style games. While this game has all of them it still manages to break through the stereotypes and manages to be a grate game. 

Even if you don't like JRPG's i would still recommend it, it has an interesting story with well written and likeable characters. Even the urn based combat has some interesting mechanics that help keep things interesting. The tone and style of the game is also top notch, and also the music has badgers front to back. 

While the dungeon crawling and the graphics hasn't aged particularly well its still playable, and i still believe the persona games have some of the best enemy designs ever. You can tell ATLUS put i large amount of effort in to making even the low level common enemy's look great.

Overall if you've never played a JRPG before if you actually give it a chance you will have a great time.

140006746.review:
So not long after The emotional roller-coaster that was persona 5, I just had to get more of this magic. Persona 4 golden was just the natural choice.

I admit, at first I was a little disappointed. Aside from the dated graphics and the lack of the p5 "vibe",
the game starts rather slow. No casino heist, no underdog situation. I thought "well, they probably just ramped it up in 5, while this one is rather average."

Well, I'm happy to say that I was wrong.

See, persona 4 may not have p5's insane palaces or the phantom thief swag, HOWEVER, it does have loads and loads of heart. With a spectacular OST, a cast of adorkable friends, the loveliness of the small town Inaba, and the absolute cinnamon roll that is Nanako.

Furthermore, the slice of life events and the whole group dynamic here is even better than 5. The phantom thieves are great as a fighting team, and I mostly prefer them as individuals. But as a group of friends that hang out together, joke around and make you smile with them? The group here takes the cake. If p5's focused on being rebellious and cool, this one is about happiness and friendship, and it shows.

The story is complex, intriguing, and the theme of truth really resonates with the twist and turns of the plot.
You want to go in blind, and you want to have multiple save files. Believe me, getting the true, full, best ending is an amazing experience. When I was finally done, I felt like someone put a sun in my heart. "Wholesome" is an understatement.

So do yourself a favor, and give this game a try.
There's a good chance it will make you happier.

While I think the game could've done with some extra time to finish some of the more optional tasks, in the end they didn't ever feel like they were truly necessary. I would still recommend players refer to a walkthrough, as finishing everything required to access the True Ending can be a challenge otherwise.
For players who enjoy a narrative experience with the occasional gameplay-heavy sections, try this game. I truly feel like it will be a timeless masterpiece.

139722701.review:
Persona 4 Golden is a good game.  I make this statement up front knowing the complaints I am going to levy against it later, but in my heart of hearts, despite these complaints, I cannot say I did not enjoy my time with the game.

The game is old, having initially being released in 2008, the gold edition coming 4 years later in 2012.  To expect such a game to have all the bells and whistles would be unfair on it.  A large part of this lies with me.  Having seen that the Persona franchise allows for one to play more up-to-date titles without missing much from the previous games, I decided to start with Persona 5.  This with the benefit of hindsight was a mistake.  By doing this comparison to the previous titles would be unavoidable, and indeed that is what happened.
I do not want this to come off as a pure dump on the game, however.  From a story and character perspective I believe that 4 may very well exceed 5.  The characters for the most part being grounded with interesting quirks and an enjoyable group dynamic never failed to make me smile when they all got together.  Even some of the, what could be considered, side characters had some of the most interesting character concepts I could think of.

In terms of story, having seen the initial twist during a friend of mines run-through meant I was not surprised when it inevitably happened in mine.  My friend however never having known of or going for the “True” ending meant I was in for a big surprise when I stumbled upon it myself.

My main issue with the game is unfortunately the “game” aspect of it itself.  The dungeon running and battle system is very dated and so I find myself wondering, would the game be better if it stuck to the visual novel aspects of the story and characters, while removing the more grindy elements?  A older fan would probably say no, and even I struggle to hold up that idea.  The story in part works because of those grindy elements.

If you are looking to pick up the Persona series and you are looking to determine which one to start with, I would say do not go in reverse order like I have now committed to.  It will invite unfair comparisons which will only make you frustrated.  Start with this one (or Persona 3, which I still need to get to) and go from there.

Pros:
•	Interesting dynamic characters with some of the most interesting and thought-provoking concepts I 
        have seen in a long time.
•	A story with a lot of twists and turns which will keep you interested and invested until the end.

Cons:
•	An unfortunately outdated combat system that will descend into heavy grinding if you want to max out 
        or having to keep the difficulty low to abuse the increase in experience gain.

139394952.review:
Now that I just install this game for a second playthrough I though "hey lets give my 2 cents to the game too"

If you love turn based jrpgs that are on the little harder side of the genre, this game is for you.
If you love a well written story with plot twists and really good characters, this is for you.
If you like pokemon and look for something more adult, this is for you.

That said without spoilering too much this game is abut efficient time management in the first place.
Basic activities during your normal daily life progress the game time (After school/Evening/Sleep)
And you have less than one year (ingame) time to avoid the end of the world.
In that time you care for social contacts, go to high school and do all kind of activities.
On top of that you also beat dungeons and level your characters. 

The difficult is generally higher when you are used to final fantasy, still not as punishing as main series 
Shin Megami Tensei titles but still not super casual.
Basically the enemies can use the so called "press turn system" (when you or the enemy attack a weakness you and them can attack again.) just like your own characters. 
But if you have fun with a little more challenging content the game is gonna be a blast for you.

139358247.review:
If you're wondering whether to get this after playing Persona 5 Royal, there are a couple major differences that I found after playing P5R:
1. The dungeons are not built like Palaces. Rather, they are more like Mementos, with the classic dungeon crawler vibe.
2. There's no way to specifically sneak. You have to actually avoid enemies or just run away. This may not seem big, but I think it affects the gameplay a lot.
3. You don't capture or negotiate with Shadows. Rather, there is a random card game that can get you money, exp, Personas, skill cards, etc. The game will explain it to you better.
4. Just in general, I think some of the scaling is a little different. I definitely find it harder than Persona 5.

Overall, I think it's a fun game and I'd recommend it, but just know that there are some differences between this and P5R. Fundamentally they're still the same, but if you like P5R for certain aspects, just know that they may not be in this game.

139341370.review:
Pros
- Once again, Persona has a large cast of extremely fun and interesting characters. If one doesn't catch your eye, others are bound to whether it's by design, personality, or anything else.
- Engaging story that's extremely interesting so far. It will leave you excited and wanting to play more to figure out what's happening.
- Charming Graphics. Even though they are old, the still hold up for their time, at least character model wise.
- Character voices. Some characters like Yosuke, Adachi, and Dojima for example give great voiced performances that are fun and investing to watch. (this point is also continued in cons.)
- Great for those who love dungeon crawlers akin to games like Pokemon Mystery Dungeon as ever level in the TV world is set up as a dungeon crawler where each level changes layout randomly.

cons:
- Voice... again. While other voice acting performances are great, others give performances that are just okay or... for lack of a better term, entirely unconvincing. Chie's voice actor talks like she's talking at the screen and not to and with other characters.
- Inconsistent in it's overall tone and morals at times. The main moral of P4 is that you should be free to be who you want to be and have your own freedom to choose so. The character Kanji is a prime example of this con. His sexuality is left ambiguous, but it is implied he's queer. Giving him the freedom to be unlabeled is fine, and even a great a choice I think! But in writing his back story, the only reason he ever questioned it was because he thought women were too mean because they called him gay or made fun of his feminine hobbies which led to him only being around men and made him question his interests in romance... Implying your only queer character is queer because they were possibly 'confused' or pushed into it by others being cruel has... absolutely reductive implications that are rooted in the very stereotypes they were trying to avoid. In a later scene, there is an entire joke around the idea of this character committing sexual assault just because he is queer. Persona has never really been good at following the own morals they set though, so I'm not really surprised. 
- Very outdated humor. Something I wont hold against the game entirely as it's a product of it's time, but something to watch out for if you're upset or sensitive to this. (i.e: Fatphobic jokes, Homophobic jokes, etc.)

EDIT: Teddie is the most annoying creature in existence and the day I find out how to punt his bear ass into the sun is the day wars will end

[h1] Reseña Apresurada [/h1]

Tras acabar por primera vez el juego, a lo fresco puedo decir:

[list]
    [*]Muy inmersivo como cualquier Persona
    [*]El OST del juego es una obra maestra
    [*]Algunos Social Links se sienten apresurados o forzados, pero de igual manera emotivos.
    [*]El equipo de investigación es otro más que resulta fácil de encariñar y empatizar, pero...
    [*]Teddie LRCDTM
    [*]Las mazmorras son muy genéricas a partir de su tercer piso, al igual que las sombras que solo cambian de diseño ([b]no es algo malo como tal que reprocharle al juego debido al año que salió, pero después de pasarme el P5R, se siente el bajón[/b])
    [*]La obtención de estadísticas sociales esta algo desbalanceada.
    [*]Los jefes son por lo general muy retadores.
    [*]El aura de misterio es sin duda el alma del juego.
    [*]Recolecte tantos items para apenas utilizar ni siquiera el 10% de ellos.
    [*]Las interacciones graciosas, reflexivos o tristes cuando todo el grupo esta reunido son de los mejores momentos.
    [*]Villanos principales cuestionables, tanto para bien como para mal.
    [*]Hermosos finales, tanto el vanilla como el golden.
[/list]

[h1] 9.5/10 [/h1]

Otro juegazo de pies a cabeza, lo disfrute más de lo que esperaba en un comienzo. Llegaría a 10 si tan solo tuviese alguna manera de sacarle la mrd al oso.

138937280.review:
Receta de la tarta de mandarina
Postres y tartas
Española
Elaboración20 min
Cocinado20 min
Tiempos de reposo30 min
Tiempo total1 h 10 min
6 personas
Ingredientes
Para la base de la tarta

125 g de harina de repostería
100 g de azúcar
75 g de almendra molida
100 g de mantequilla fría
1 huevo para pincelar la masa

Para la crema de mandarina

100 g de azúcar
La piel de 2 mandarinas
350 g de agua
150 g de zumo de mandarina
3 yemas de huevo
50 g de maicena

Para terminar tu tarta

3 mandarinas (depende del tamaño)
1 cucharada de mantequilla
2 cucharada de mermelada de naranja

Puedes prorratear los ingredientes a otras cantidades usando nuestra calculadora
Preparación

Disponible también:

Para Cook Expert
Para Thermomix

Elaboración de la masa

Corta la mantequilla en pequeños dados.
Pon todos los ingredientes menos el huevo en un cuenco. Mezcla, pero sin trabajar mucho la masa, lo justo para que se unan los ingredientes.
Haz una bola y aplánala un poco. Métela media hora en el frigorífico envuelta en plástico transparente.
Extiende la masa sobre un trozo de plástico transparente, cúbrela con otro y aplánala con un rodillo.
Engrasa la base del molde. Fórralo con la masa. Retira la masa restante con los propios dedos. La masa es arenosa y delicada. Lee los consejos porque te doy otras dos opciones de masa más sencillas, por si no te atreves con ésta.
Pincela la superficie con huevo batido y pincha toda la masa con un tenedor.
Mete en el frigorífico durante 5 minutos.
Precalienta el horno a 200ºC, calor arriba y abajo.
Baja la temperatura a 180ºC y hornea unos 15 minutos.

Elaboración de la crema

Lava bien las mandarinas y ralla su piel. Reserva. Haz zumo con ellas y reserva igualmente.
Pon el agua, el zumo de mandarina, las yemas, la maicena, el azúcar y la ralladura en un cazo. Ponlo a fuego medio y no dejes de remover hasta que espese, aproximadamente de unos 8 a 10 minutos. Reserva hasta que enfríe poniendo un plástico transparente tocando la superficie de la crema para que no cree costra.

Para terminar

Pela las mandarinas que van a cubrir la tarta, quitando bien toda la parte blanca. Córtalas en rodajas.
Pon la cucharada de mantequilla en una sartén antiadherente a fuego medio y pasa las rodajas de mandarina uno segundos por cada lado. De esta manera quedan un poco blanditas y con un sabor delicioso.

138611662.review:
[h1][b]Sí, yo también jugué P5ROYAL antes que este[/b][/h1]

Persona 4 Golden (lo que vendría a ser la versión Royal de Persona 4), un título que nos pone en la piel de un estudiante en el apacible pueblo rural de Inaba. Pero lo que parecía que sería un curso tranquilo, pronto se tornará en todo un thriller en el que deberemos resolver unos misteriosos asesinatos que están teniendo lugar en el pueblo.

Pese a que Persona 4 se siente diferente a su quinta entrega, ya que nos aparta del bullicio de Tokyo, para llevarnos a un apacible pueblo en el campo. Al mismo tiempo también es el que más se le parece y quienes vengan de la quinta entrega se van a sentir como pez en el agua, ya la cuarta entrega fue la precursora de muchos de los sistemas que hay en Persona 5, aunque algo menos refinados, como es lógico.

Por lo tanto, los social links, el tener que gestionar qué hacemos en nuestro tiempo libre o con quién lo pasamos, el sistema de relevos o la captura de personas en los combates, todo lo que hizo grande a Persona 5 lo vamos a tener aquí en mayor o menor medida. Y eso, unido a una historia bastante diferente, junto con otro grupo de compañeros entrañables y carismáticos, dan como resultado un JRPG que se puede medir de tú a tú con cualquier otro más actual.

Quizás en lo que falla más sea en el diseño de sus mazmorras… Todas ellas resultan un tanto simplonas y además son procedurales, nada que ver con los sensacionales Palacios que veríamos después en Persona 5. Pero por lo demás, podríamos decir que poco tiene que envidiarle a la quinta entrega. Ni siquiera la música, pues P4G también cuenta con un repertorio sublime con un «flow» muy parecido al de P5.

En definitiva, si jugaste P5, juega P4. Si te gustan los JRPG's, juega P4. Sea como sea, JUEGA P4 GOLDEN.

138321897.review:
Didn't realize Persona 4 is 11 years old when I bought it. But that isn't the issue I have with it. I mainly picked it up because of all the good things I've heard about the series.

Even though it was not originally for PC. This is one of those games that need an extended period for a refund. Because, my god, the beginning takes sooooo long. It feels like 80% dialog. By the time you can move around freely and you have took your time letting the voice acting (which is pretty good for its time) play out. You have reached at least 1 hour of game time. Maybe 1.5 hours. If you care about your refund window. You will want to demo this somehow before paying for it.

The music is so GD repetitive and uncreative. The budget clearly went into the anime cut scene art. The art is everything you'd expect from anime from 2012. So they nailed it there. With the 4th iteration of the series you'd think they would have had a larger budget. When I continue playing next time the music is going off. 

Some of the combat mechanics make little to no sense. Rushing (when all of them attack at once, I can't remember term exactly at the time of writing this) does laughably little damage. It feels like it was just added in for the lolz. Because when you attack separately. You can literally do 3-4x the damage compared to when they attack at once.
Also, why do your characters surround the enemy all the time? Outside of battle your position matters *a lot*. So why are your characters magically surrounding them. All it does it make the battlefield seem messy (yes, irl combat is messy but its a video game...) and makes the camera fly around a lot.

Combining Personas and the Personas themselves doesn't make much sense either. They have seemingly random skills. You would expect them to say, for example, the pixie and angel to be healing and/or confusion, but they don't? Maybe I overlooked it?

If you don't like social mechanics then this is another issue. Personally, I find social time exhausting. Having to maintain and/or developing it with non-fiction characters is just as exhausting.

Maybe it is my monitor (even though I have the gamma lowered a bit). But the colors are ridiculously bright. Maybe this is from the HD graphics remake. They should have toned it down a little. Play with a controller on your largest monitor and sit back a bit so you're not constantly blinded in the menu anytime you have to open it.

Speaking of controllers. Play it with a controller. The keyboard controls feel clunky. There is very little room to remap any of the controls. Your character also moves in a very 8 directional way with no leeway to move outside of them.

Performance wise I have no real complaints. You have a few options to crank the anti-aliasing to max, vsync and 120fps, borderless, and resolution. There's a few bugs here and there that are noticeable at the beginning. But that's really it. Overall not that bad of a port.

Storyline is OK. But overall I'm having a hard time seeing the hype with this series. I'm hoping it will reveal itself later after a few more key points in the story reveal itself.

I'll probably have more to add later. But for the moment I am glad it was only $20. Might want to buy it on sale.

138297095.review:
Persona 4 Golden is an updated version of the original Persona 4 game, developed by Atlus and released exclusively on the PlayStation Vita. The game features new content, fully voiced dialogue, and improved graphics, among other changes.

The gameplay in Persona 4 Golden is similar to the original Persona 4, with players controlling a high school student who discovers he has the ability to enter a mysterious world called the TV world through a television set. In the TV world, the player can battle various creatures known as Shadows, recruit them as Persona, and use them to battle other enemies.

One of the most significant changes in Persona 4 Golden is the addition of a new character named Marie, who brings new story and dungeon content to the game. The game also features a new epilogue that expands on the story and ties up loose ends left in the original Persona 4.

The social and relationship-building elements of Persona 4 Golden have been expanded, with new events and interactions with the game's various characters. The game also features a new gardening feature that allows players to grow and harvest vegetables, which can be used in various ways in the game.

The music and graphics in Persona 4 Golden have also been improved, with remastered music tracks and updated graphics that take advantage of the Vita's high-resolution screen. The game's new cutscenes and animations add depth and immersion to the game's story and characters.

Overall, Persona 4 Golden is a fantastic re-release of an already great game. The new content, expanded social links, and updated graphics and music make it a must-play for fans of the genre, and an excellent entry point for newcomers to the Persona series.

138257439.review:
While I would hands down recommend this game for the storyline alone which is the star of the show, and how much I loved that the characters were all fleshed out, there were a lot of pain points for me when I first started going through the game, and then going through the year, which would have me waver about claiming it as one of the best games I've played.

I wish it was more apparent during the beginning phases that you need to train before doing the first boss. When I first got this game, I didn't understand why I kept losing, and then upon looking it up, I realized that I needed to grind out the monsters to get to a higher level which at the beginning is kind of frustrating.

I also felt a little overwhelmed with the day by day structure because there was so much to do, different characters having different schedules, that I personally felt without a guide I would have missed something, and didn't want to play the game more than twice.

Which leads me to my next complaint on the hardcore Risette achievement, what is the point of this achievement besides making me want to yeet a controller across the room because its so difficult to have to keep track of and ruined my 2nd play through experience since I felt forced to play with my unused characters.

I would ultimately say that this was a good Persona game for me to start off with, but because of my experience, its hard to decide whether I'd want to play another Persona game. If difficult achievements doesn't deter you then definitely go for it since the storyline is incredible. Just beware of the Risette achievement x.x

138227369.review:
I was extremely reluctant to play this game for a while based solely on the fact that I hate going back to previous entries in long running series because I know that they simply won't measure up to the later games in many objective ways. Persona 5 Royal is my 2nd favorite game of all time and I love almost every single bit of it to death. While I still loved this game, I hate being proven right. Persona 4 is without a doubt one of the most frustrating games I have ever played, while being one of the greatest games I've ever experienced.

The good (the world, story, characters and music): 
*This is a persona game through and though. It has so much heart and emotion in a way that no other medium can possibly convey. Getting to know a group of friends that slowly become inseparable over the course of dozens of hours of gameplay only to hit you with a nuclear gut punch at the very end. It's bursting at the seams with character, humor, happiness and tragedy, and dips into all manner of subject matter without straying away from its bright and happy tone. These games just make you feel good, and seeing the credits roll is like saying goodbye to a close friend.

*The music, if you can believe it, is stellar. It's nowhere close to P5's jazzy, cocky and infinitely stylish OST in my personal opinion, but you would be hard pressed to find any persona music track that isn't an absolutely transcendental banger. The songs in this game go for a more J-pop style, and every single one (with the exception of that stupid piano track that plays every time someone so much as stubs their toe) is just so damn good that it's incredible. 

*The story has plenty of twists and turns and even though I had been spoiled on the big twist, there were still a few story beats that surprised me. While it still devolves into the [spoiler] Me japanese game so now you must kill god that comes out of nowhere hurr durr [/spoiler] toward the end, the journey more than makes up for the lacklustre destination.

*The romance feels natural and is actually integrated into the story. Your choice of partner influences dialogue and how some scenes play out rather than maybe one or two dialogue changes in the entire game. This is unlike P5 where everyone randomly decides to keep it a secret, keeping %99 of the game identical no matter who you choose.
(As an aside to all this however, I have to mention the acting. While most of the english actors are really good for their roles, some of them do everything in their power to devour the scenery at every opportunity. Not only that though, you can HEAR how bad their mics are, to the point where you can hear the microphone popping in a large chunk of their lines, with rise and yukiko being the most egregious. It's annoying, it's inexcusable, but I can muscle past it.)

The bad (the gameplay):
Let's not mince words here: Persona 4's gameplay SUCKS. In fact, in terms of turn-based rpg gameplay, it's the worst I have ever played and it's not even close. The game seems almost determined to fight with the player on absolutely everything, turning what should be a tight and satisfying battle system into an agonising struggle.

*The menus and UI are crunchy, archaic and clunky as all hell. Animations don't have snap, and quickly selecting options in combat is a chore. Having to press an extra button just to see what a move does is tedious, and the fact that switching personas is an action with its own menu prompt that you can only do once per turn is nothing short of baffling. Reminder that Final Fantasy 7 came out 10 years before P4 and 14 years before Golden yet is still infinitely more fluid in its combat.

*Every single dungeon is literally exactly the same with a different coat of paint. Long dark paper-thin randomly arranged hallways with N64 draw distance filled with enemies you can only sometimes avoid, wandering around aimlessly for minutes on end to hopefully find the stairs. And god help you if the dungeon in question requires you to backtrack to find a key to progression. It's boring, and just feels like tedious meandering to make them last longer. Compared to P5's palaces, it's not even a question. Random generation works in roguelikes, survival games, DRG and nothing else.

*The enemy variety is nonexistant. You'll be seeing the same exact enemy model copied and pasted from the very beginning to the very end of the game. Not only is it boring to fight the same ball-with-mouth or haunted-table for 60 hours, but since this game is all about exploiting enemy weaknesses, the fact that they all look the same means that you have to be constantly checking the analysis menu to see if the yellow rock-with-face has a different weakness than the blue rock-with-face.

*Persona 4 thinks that making an rpg difficult means "Just don't let the player deal damage." Enemy has one weakness and nullifies everything else? That weakness will be also nullified. Enemy has no weaknesses and takes half physical damage? It also has high counter so a large portion of your attacks will be reflected. Finally got that enemy with no weakness down? This enemy randomly takes no damage from all-out-attacks. 

*The thing that murders the combat stone dead more than anything else though is the god damn fucking MISSING. I cannot even come close to overstating how fucking awful attack accuracy is in this game. It does not matter which party member is using which attack, it does not matter if you've stacked a party accuracy buff with an enemy evasion debuff, and it does not matter how many times it happens, it is not even an exaggeration to say that your attacks on similarly levelled enemies WILL miss %50 of the time. I mean it when I say that EVERY SINGLE ATTACK feels like buying a lottery ticket, and it was a COMMON occurrence to go multiple FULL ROUNDS without landing a single attack. When I was fighting one of the big story bosses, completely out of resources with my back against the wall and the boss at low health, all 4 party members missed every. single. one. of their attacks for 4 ROUNDS STRAIGHT. It's like dangling some desperately needed dopamine over the player's head while punching them in the gut over and over and over again. If that weren't enough, you can also CRIT MISS, which knocks the character over and leaves them vulnerable, which is like eating a cookie and discovering that it's full of live fire ants. And the thing is, fighting the vanilla final boss and having most of my attacks actually landing made it the most enjoyable fight in the entire game. In P5, you look forward to going into a dungeon, in P4 you dread it.

(As one last aside, it is absolutely asinine that there is [spoiler] A secret ending AFTER the first secret ending that you can only find on the last day of the game by going to an area you have no business going to after declining a choice you have literally no reason to decline. Seriously, if I hadn't made a save the day of, I would have been locked out of content that was AFTER content I was nearly locked out of. [/spoiler]

So here's the big verdict: If you can look past some truly, objectively terrible Turn-based RPG gameplay that will not hesitate to make you tear your hair out over and over, you have yourself a great story with some amazingly fun and likeable characters waiting for you, filled to the brim with heart and emotion. If you go in expecting gameplay on the same level as something like FF7 or P5, save your money and bash your head on the nearest hard surface for a similar experience. I love this game, and I hate this game.

138223686.review:
Firstly, I must say that Persona 4 Golden is a game that you can play. It has a storyline, characters, and mechanics that function within the game. The graphics are also acceptable, considering that it was originally released on the Vita.

However, if you're looking for a game that will blow your mind, you might want to look elsewhere. The game can be quite repetitive at times, with a lot of time spent on dungeon crawling and grinding levels. The combat system is decent, but can become tiresome after a while.

On the other hand, the game's storyline is engaging and well-written. The characters are also well-developed and have their own unique personalities. The game's social sim aspect is also enjoyable, as you get to interact with the characters and learn more about their lives.

But don't get too excited just yet. The game can be quite slow-paced, and the dialogue can sometimes be cringey and cheesy. Some of the character designs and outfits can also be a bit questionable if your into dudes.

In conclusion, Persona 4 Golden is a game that exists and can be played. It has its strengths and weaknesses, but ultimately it's up to the player to decide whether they enjoy it or not. So, go ahead and give it a try if you're interested.
