138035280.review:
To note, I've been playing it on the Nintendo switch for about 30-32 hours.

I've tried several times to get into this game, even during the PS2 era. However, it just never pulled me in. I tried yet again on the Nintendo switch and played well into the game this time. 

The game does an excellent job of creating an eerie-atmosphere that compliments the mystery presented to you of "Who did it?" 

The music is very great at times, but sometimes feels out of place....as though it belongs more appropriately in the future Persona 5. Sometimes the music is weirdly absent at times that you think music should be present. 

Almost all the side characters are stereotypes, but considering how long ago this game was first made.....I can give that a pass. 

I suppose the real issue is this. I like the idea behind the Persona games more than the execution. Persona 4 is no different. 
There are two big reasons why I can't recommend this game. 

1. The gameplay is incredibly repetitive with zero thrills. Leveling up becomes incredibly tiresome when you reach level 20 and you're running through the same dungeon fighting the exact same enemies.......even same room locations.......for the 20th time.  Sure you can get "stronger" personas, but that itself feels repetitive as well. I will explain below.

You can literally put ANY move on ANY persona, even if it seems contrary to the nature of that persona(making an ice persona use fire attacks). On one hand I can appreciate the freedom to customize persona's, but I can't help feel like there isn't any personas that are unique. Why should there be any unique personas when you can make them all the same with the same attacks? The stat differences really don't matter much unless you're comparing the level of personas to have a 10-15 levels difference.  A level 12 persona will really be compareable in stats up to a level 22 persona.  So, all the leveling in between those levels is to possibly gain new moves(which you can spam later). 

The daily life interactions/jobs/school clubs/jobs...........is a good idea in general, but when you're in that much of a time crunch to level up before the next challenge than such activities feels more tedious than enjoyable. I suppose it ultimately doesn't matter a lot since none of the activities are engrossing or interactive. You can try to say "Well this game came out like 15 years ago and the technology wasn't available to do such things". 

That's hogwash. Shemmue came out 10 years earlier than P4 and did it better. 

2. The bad guy is obvious from nearly the beginning. One of the worst things that can be done in a "Who done it?" mystery is make the bad guy an easily identifiable individual. 

I will say that P4 is not a bad game for what it is, but don't try to use it's age as an excuse for it's shortcomings. 7 out of 10

138015924.review:
86 hours. How many entire single player only, narrative games can boast that they can keep you engaged and playing for 86 hours for ONE play-through, and all you can think about at the end is planning the next play-through?

It's weird to love a game so much and not even know how to describe it. Is this a JRPG? Is this a visual novel? A dating sim? A perfectly crafted time management game? Is it a noir detective game? Is it a comedy? A drama? It's everything all at once to the point I couldn't even neatly sum up one thing that it really "is". IT just kinda does everything all at once, seamlessly blending it without feeling messy. 

This game also perfects the kind of gameplay loop that is just catnip to me, which is the "just one more" setup, with no microtransactions, just offers little packages of fun one after the other. Like, a game like stronghold, or any dungeon match games, idk a good example (any game with clearly defined levels) - you have a game, or scenario, and you win or lose, and then the level is over. You have an easy and natural stopping point. If you win "that's enough, let's go on a high note" or "screw this, I lost! *quits game*". This game keeps you playing. Just one more day! A day is a short, easy, bitesize unit of time, that it feels inconsequential to play just one more of, then suddenly you save the game and two hours have passed. The same way a paradox map game just kinda goes on with no clear time breaks, "just one more war", this has the same feeling that sucks you into a game you love to focus on. I think part of that is that it's a semi-open world. A full open world game with a gigantic map gives you too much freedom, you can run around, waste time with side missions, and wander back to the world ending calamity whenever you damn well please. A fully linear game lets you blow through it with no time to pace yourself. This game keeps the urgency up, gives you only so much time to do everything, while still feeling like you HAVE a lot of choice in what to do. It is not restrictive, while keeping up the tension that TES games lose when you ignore the apocalypse to go and fight trolls or join the bard's guild for nine in-game months. 

The story is superb, every time I thought "oh X hasn't happened for a while they need to keep the stakes up" it would happen within a day or two. I did see a few things coming, but I think they were kinda signposted anyway, and because it was naturally the correct story decision TO happen next in terms of good writing. The pacing is generally done well, and the story balances drama and intensity with humour and levity in waves that are so well spaced out. The funny moments are genuinely sweet and funny, the dramatic moments are just that. While I was unsure of the game for the first 2 hours, when it semed to be JUST a visual novel, I'm glad I pressed on, and it makes sense to have that long of an intro considering how vast the story is. No joke, I first started this game, played for about 8 hours solid, then proceeded to do the same for pretty much every day for a month, until I was done. I worked a full time jobs' worth of time playing this. This WAS my April. I would do whatever I had to do that day, then play this for 8 hours straight, fall alseep and dream about playing it, or it's story, or characters, for another 8 hours, then repeat. Yes, I genuinely, actually just dreamed bout the game the majority of nights during the time I played it. 

Everything about the story, the assets, the scenery, the MUSIC, was nostalgic (for a game I never even played before) bitter-sweet, amazing, enrapturing. I got lost in this game, and fell in love with so many original characters that just endear themselves to you beyond words. It also shows you just how vast it is, that you can press a button to see the choices others made on a given day, and like 7 months in, you can see most people hung out with a character YOU DIDN'T EVEN MEET YET! The combat was balanced and felt challenging and fun as well, everything was just done great. Even when I was months away from the end of the game, I would deliberately take the time to slow down, read every prompt slowly ,and admire the scenery, the music, the assets, and live in the moment, to enjoy every last second, the whole environments they created, with unique assets, to just be in this one scene. I would drag out time to simply VIBE with the game, and no other game has made me cherish every last moment playing it as much.

My nitpicks, for fairness:
Maybe it's due to being an old game, but how they dealt with LGBT characters felt a bit... off, with how their journeys concluded. Not in a horrific way, just, without spoilers, I think it would be handled differently by a 2023 story, and felt like a cop out from making them LGBT to begin with. This applies most closely to the final team member, as well as another character, but 2009 gonna 2009 I guess. 

The villain: NYOOOOOOOOOOO

They hold off on other characters romancing one another so that you, as the player, have the option to date/cheat on everyone. But, I kinda wish there were story branches for pushing the other characters to date each other if you've already picked someone, or just want to see that outcome for the others. And it might be nice to have your relationship be a bit more public, since it's kinda forced to be kept a secret to keep up the charade for players who choose to be a cheater, which means whoever you date can't have AS big an impact on the story as it might otherwise have. 

No girl protagonist! NO GIRL PROTAGONIST. Since the MC is so bland/self inserty, I don't see how it would be so hard to just offer an asset/dialogue swap for a girl protagonist with a few romantic options added to open up all genders. 

Cannot rebind move to the arrow keys. While this did lead me to playing with a PS4 controller, which I ultimately think was the best choice, I always mark a game down for accessibility for left handed players when they arbitrarily disallow using the arrow keys for movement. If I didn't happen to own a console, that would have made the game boarderline unplayable for me. 

Good ending is locked behind a complex dialogue tree that you can only break through with a game guide - I think it should be a tad easier to access the last quarter of the game, because without the internet to tell me this was multi-ending, I would have assumed the game just ended like that, or at least assume that I must have soft locked a good ending out accidentally months before.

Some of the side quests were too arbitrary to complete, even a pretty basic one I wasted months building a social link to complete, just to discover that's not how you complete it at all.

How some things work aren't signposted QUITE clearly enough, so I avoided doing some things until way too late bc I assumed they'd be mandatory once I began. Kinda my fault, but still.

While I did enjoy my time grinding, and felt that the amount of grinding you did balanced your time spent outside of dungeons well, I think the outcome of fights was tied to it a little too much. It takes the feeling of skill out of a battle if the the difference between getting wiped, and wiping the boss is just a few grind levels, and not smarter tactics. 

However long my list of nitpicks is, it really is JUST nitpicks, which only stand out as a problem due to the fact that everything else is so wonderfully perfect.

I'll hold off on saying this is my all time favourite game for now, due to recency bias, but I imagine it'll probably take the top spot from Watch_Dogs for most enjoyed/replayed single player story for sure, and is better crafted and more intricate overall. This game was also a Christmas gift so THANK YOU John! I won't forget it :)

137997418.review:
One of my all-time favorite games, I first played this on my PS Vita.
It's the best of the Persona Series (Yes even better than 5).

Graphics: 7/10
The game has the perfect atmosphere and the graphics, though VERY dated (2008 graphics) it is still serviceable and adds to the overall feel of the game.

Gameplay: 8/10
The gameplay is your typical turn-based RPG with a mix of visual-novel esque elements. If you're not into those, this game probably isn't for you.

Story: 10/10
IMO, it has the strongest story of any of the 'Modern' Persona games. It also has more relatable Social Links compared to the confidants of 5 and more interesting characters compared to 3. The character arc of the main protagonist and of everyone in the game is really the main highlight of the entire game. By the end of the game you really feel like everyone grew out of their shells.

Soundtrack: 12/10
Its literally a Persona game. its impossible for the score to be lower than a 10.
Also hearing snowflakes on a normal day when you know its all about to be over soon is actually heartbreaking..

Voice Acting: 13/10
EVERYONE did a bang up job here. Maybe I can point out one that was a little bland, and thats Yumi. Other than that, the VA's all did a fantastic job making these group of kids feel like ACTUAL friends. It makes me genuinely smile when there are random little skits that show how close they are cause you can feel their warmth.

If you don't mind the Turn-Based RPG + Visual Novel hybrid gameplay (which I know is already a dealbreaker for most), I highly recommend this game. 
Its one of my all-time faves.

137975802.review:
The premise is really awesome. The characters are great, the writing is great, the story is great. But goddamn are the dungeons extremely tedious and boring. All of them are literally just fucking hallways. If you played P5, they're all literally Mementos. The combat is... fine. It's very average turn based combat, nothing special.

One thing the port does extremely well is they let you create a custom difficulty. You can customize damage input/output, EXP gained, and Money gained. You can also make it so if you die, you can retry the battle or restart the floor you're on.

If you want an autistic grind, set that shit on Very Hard. But honestly I don't enjoy the combat enough to justify the amount of time spent in it, so I increase my damage output and increase Money and EXP gained.

If you're coming from P5, you are straight up not going to enjoy the gameplay as much. But you gotta set that aside, because again, the story, the writing, and the premise make this game pretty awesome.

EDIT: Please someone get me away from this fucking game so I can stop crying. I cannot stress this enough: play this game. It will make you feel emotions you never thought you had.

137941252.review:
A masterpiece that should not be overshadowed by Persona 5. If you're in for stories, this would be a must-play from me. 

In here you are thrown into Inaba as a transfer student. You experience life with a group of pals who all have their own background stories, followed by different journeys they are taking to overcome and accept themselves while solving the serial murder emerging in the quiet town. 

I really love the theme and the illustration about the 'self' throughout every part of the main story, the script writers did not slack off while writing the separate episodic character developmental arcs - and it is a real challenge to link up every episode soundly! These sub-arcs complement the main story while they are also individual and complete stories on their own, making it a harmonious interplay between the two concepts. If there aren't the sub-arcs, the main story would not be complete, vice versa. The characters, be them the deuteragonists, or the minor support characters, are all fully developed personalities who I can really imagine as real people. I can picture laughing and crying with them, and I never had such sentiments for the P5 characters (not that they're bad, just not comparable to the writing in P4G).

There are some segments of the story focusing on (obligatory - for such genre and setting) high school humor, but they do not derail from the main theme of 'self', that the shadow and the persona are just the two sides of a coin. It would be unfair and ignorant to simply call P4G a 'typical high school anime boys and girls story'. What they successfully illustrated is that there are indeed ups and downs in life, and the motto is to remain honest to oneself and those who one can trust, and not to distort whatever you hold as a rationale bona fide. 

Want some good laughs or somehow you want to shed some genuine tears? P4G got you covered, and both. Complexity does not necessitate darkness and sorrow, P4 Golden delivers an engaging plot that does not trade 'youth, friendship and happiness' away just to appear deep or solemn. 

(By the last paragraph I did not mean to say that P3 is bad, and I only heard even better things about P3 in storytelling. I don't think I can stand the old system there though.)
